revision.text:
{{distinguish|Dark ride}} '''Black light theatre''' (in [[Czech language|Czech]] ''černé divadlo'') or simply '''black theatre''', is a theatrical performance style characterized by the use of [[black box theatre]] augmented by [[black light]] illusion. This form of theatre originated from Asia and can be found in many places around the world. It has become a speciality of [[Prague]], where many theatres use it.<ref name=HILTPRESS>http://blacklighttheatre.wbs.cz/tisk-press.html</ref>
The distinctive characteristics of "black theatre" are the use of black curtains, a darkened stage, and "black lighting" (UV light), paired with [[fluorescent]] costumes in order to create intricate visual illusions. This "black cabinet" technique was used by [[Georges Méliès]], and by theatre revolutionary [[Konstantin Stanislavski]] (especially in his [[List of productions directed by Konstantin Stanislavski|production]] of ''[[Cain (play)|Cain]]''). The technique, paired with the expressive artistry of dance, [[mime]] and acrobatics of the performers is able to create remarkable spectacles.<ref name=tafantastika>http://www.tafantastika.cz/en/black-light-theatre/index.php#</ref>
==Optics==
A key principle of black light theatre is the inability of the human eye to distinguish black objects from a black background. This effect results in effective invisibility for any objects not illuminated by the 'black light'.<ref name=tafantastika /> The second optical principle behind black light theatre is the effect of UV light on fluorescent objects. Black lights actually emit as much light as 'normal' lights, but at a frequency that humans cannot detect. While most objects either absorb UV light or reflect it back at the same frequency at which it came in, fluorescent objects absorb UV light then re-emit it at a longer wavelength that human eyes can detect.<ref name=illinois.edu>http://van.physics.illinois.edu/qa/listing.php?id=1913</ref> The combined effect is that designers can make some objects appear as bright as if the room were fully lighted, while making other objects appear as dark as if the room were completely dark.
==History== The 'black box trick' of using performers dressed in black in a dark playing space has been in use for millennia, starting with the jugglers performing for the emperor in ancient China.<ref name=cernedivadlo>http://www.cernedivadlo.cz/theatre.htm</ref> Japan developed this technique in its [[Bunraku Theatre]] by having puppeteers wear black in order to place complete emphasis on the puppet.<ref name=puppetsnow>http://www.puppetsnow.com/history-of-puppets.html</ref> In modern theatre the black box trick has been adopted up by Russian director [[Konstantin Stanislavski]], film director [[George Melies]], and various French avantgarde directors of the 1950s. Among these directors, George Lafaye became an earlier pioneer of black cabinet.<ref name=tafantastika /> But all these directors used the simple trick of black cabinet just for few moments during their performances mostly to make something on the stage disappear.
The father of modern black light theatre, author of the principe of black cabinet as is used nowadays (placement of spot lights, placement of uv lights, selection of black velvet as the best material to absorb residual light on the scene...) and even author of the name "black light theatre" and so the creator of the 1st black light theatre in the world is Jiri Srnec. The first performance of the ensemble took place in 1959 in Vienna. It became better known after its participation in the Theatre Festival in Edinburgh in 1962. Later, other groups using the technique of black box appeared starting the new wave of this theatre style.<ref name=srnectheatre>http://www.srnectheatre.com/en/about_us.html</ref>
Prague has since become the home of black light theatre with around 10 black light theatre companies .<ref name="HILTPRESS" /><ref name=cernedivadlotour>http://www.cernedivadlo.cz/festivals-and-awards.htm</ref><ref>[http://www.imagetheatre.cz/en/trips-and-activities/ Image Theatre tours]</ref><ref>[http://www.tafantastika.cz/en/repertoire/on-tour.php name=tafantastikatour]</ref><ref name=badmintontheater>[http://www.badmintontheater.gr/show_event_en.asp?eid=151 Badminton Theatre]</ref>
Another well-known group of black light theatre is black light theatre HILT Prague,<ref>[http://hilt-theatre.cz Hilt Theatre Web]</ref> whose performances are based on modern music and dance choreographies, and has incorporated live singing. The group was founded in 2006 by Czech dancer, choreographer, director and music composer Theodor Hoidekr.<ref>[http://hilt-theatre.cz/times2.jpeg Times of India]</ref> In 2016 was founded the new black light theatre style called "[https://www.hilt-theatre.cz/Shadow-theatre-HILT.html shadow film theatre]" by the group HILT Prague. Except black light theatre shows they present also the first shadow film theatre - dancers and actors are playing with their shadows on the screen with projections of real places.
==Modern dance in black light theatre== In 1989 the [http://www.imagetheatre.cz/en/performance/ Image Theatre] was founded by dancer Eva Asterova (former member of Pavel Smok's famous Czech ballet company) and Alexander Cihar. They brought new aspects into black light theatre effects such as modern dance and non-verbal acting. Under the hand of Eva Asterová, the theatre's artistic director, Image seeks to produce an individual look of at a scene’s signature. The audience also often becomes an integral part of the performance. The repertory of the Image theatre is composed of its own devised works. Apart from Eva Asterová there are also other authors cooperating repeatedly on Image Theatre's performances such as Josef Tichý, Petr Liška, René Pyš or Zdeněk Zdeněk. Since the beginning, Image Theatre had presented 10 different performances <ref>Black light Image Theatre: http://www.imagetheatre.cz/en/performance/</ref> and in each of them they came with some new black light technique effects. Magic poetics, playfulness, and humor are the most important trademarks of this ensemble.
The Image theatre has 22 years experience in Prague’s black light theatres scene. Apart from regular performances in Prague, Image also performs internationally (Korea, Hong Hong, Macau, Israel, Turkey, India, Lebanon, Greece, Germany, France, Italy, Switzerland, Belgium, Hungary, Slovakia, Cyprus).
==Black light theatre today== [[File:BLACK LIGHT THEATRE HILT 11.jpg|thumb|350px|Only parts of this performer's body can be seen because of the special costume.]]
Nowadays there are many companies of black light theatre also out of Prague (Hungary, Germany,<ref>http://www.velvets-theater.de</ref> USA) trying to make shows similar to black light theatres in Prague. Prague scene has changed its face to the style of 20th century - modern dance was involved, costume designs have become more effective, black light theatre shows have become more musical. Prague is still home of black light theatre - hundreds thousands of tourists visit their shows every month.
[https://hilt-theatre.cz HILT] - the black light theatre of Theodor Hoidekr was the first ever who has involved live singing into black light show. The most popular HILT´s black light theatre musical show was "Juliet´s Dream" premiered on 14 February 2012 in Prague. HILT is working on new style of black light theatre - all the members are experienced in black light theatres all over Prague. Its founder and director Theodor Hoidekr was originally dancer who later started to work with black light theatre style. His experiences comes from Prague, Slovakia, Germany, Malta, Greece, South America, India <ref name=HILT>http://www.hilt-theatre.cz/tisk-press.html</ref>
Since 8 April 2015 HILT performs the new show [https://hilt-theatre.cz "Phantom"] that is the world first black light theatre version of the mysterious phantom figure. The black light theatre HILT starts the new part of their history in theatre Royal Prague. In 2016 HILT has presented the first [https://www.hilt-theatre.cz/home/cinderella-shadow-theatre/ shadow film theatre Cinderella].
In 2017 HILT has moved to the Prague popular U Valsu Theatre in the centre of the Old Prague. 2.6.2017 they start to present also their best of called Phantom (best of 2007 - 2017) that is the combination show of black light theatre, shadow theatre.and projections. This show was the only Czech theatre and the only black light theatre presented at [https://www.mzv.cz/newdelhi/en/pr/culture/black_light_theatre.html 8th World Theatre Olympics 2018] in India.
==In Performance== [[File:Beo Beyond Costume design.jpg|thumb|220px|Fluorescent costume under UV light. Created by the artist Beo Beyond]] The effect of black light theatre allows invisible performers to move visible props, turning the objects into independent participants in the theatre at the same level as the human actors.<ref name=tafantastika /> Furthermore, the appearance of objects and actors in a performance can be sudden and can occur anywhere on stage, even within a few meters of an audience member.<ref name=badmintontheater /> In order to achieve this effect it is necessary to create an intense field of UV light throughout the entire playing space. Because the intensity of light emitted from a typical 'black light' source diminishes significantly with increased distance from the source, covering an entire theatre space with UV light requires either that the 'black light' sources be spaced as close as one meter apart or emit much more light than a typical 'black light'.<ref name=theatrefx>http://www.theatrefx.com/funfacts2.html</ref> Another important consideration is that, since most of the space is completely dark, and the form is heavily dance based, a single wrong move by a single performer can negatively impact the entire production. For this reason performers train extensively specifically for the black light theatre environment.
Contemporary black light theatre often includes many highly technical devices, in addition to the standard 'black light' technique. Such devices can include "flying" performers, large video projections,<ref>Image Theatre: http://www.imagetheatre.cz/en/afrikania/</ref> and even massive puppets.<ref name=tafantastika /> These technical devices serve as a significant factor in black light theatre's worldwide popularity; since its most important devices are entirely visual, audiences throughout the world can understand most black light theatre performances.<ref name=pragueexperience>http://www.pragueexperience.com/theatre/theatres.asp</ref> The intended result is a theatrical work that combines grand spectacle with beautiful and moving art.<ref name=tafantastika /> Major companies currently producing black light theatre include Srnec Theatre, HILT, Ta Fantastika Theatre, Image Theatre, Metro Theatre, and All Colours Theatre.<ref name=pragueexperience />
==References== {{Reflist}}
== External links == * [https://hilt-theatre.cz HILT - black light theatre Prague of Theodor Hoidekr] * [https://www.hilt-theatre.cz/home/cinderella-shadow-theatre/ The first black light and shadow film theatre Prague] * [http://www.srnectheatre.com/ Black Light Theatre Srnec - the 1st black light theatre in the world - since 1961] * [http://www.velvets-theater.de Velvets Theater, Wiesbaden, Germany] * [http://www.imagetheatre.cz/en/ IMAGE THEATRE - black light theatre of Prague] * [http://www.blacklight-theatre.com/ Black Light Theatre World Web] * [http://www.blacktheatreprague.cz/ Black Light Theatre of Prague] * [http://www.wow-show.com/en/ Black Light Theatre Wow Show Prague ] * [http://www.beobeyond.com Black light performance and costumes ] * [http://www.blacklight-event.wbs.cz/ The newest Prague BLT group - Hoidekr Interactive Light Theatre ] on [[YouTube]]. * [http://www.hilt-theatre.cz/other-languages.html Black Light Theatre page by Google translate in all languages ] * [http://www.schwarzlicht-theater.de/ Schwarzlichttheater in Konstanz], Schwarzlichttheater in Konstanz * [http://facebook.com/zauberlichttheater/], ZauberLicht Theater- mobile, international, blacklight theater from Germany

{{Use mdy dates|date=March 2015}} {{Infobox person | name = Bob Eubanks | image = Bob Eubanks KRLA 1964.jpg | caption = Bob Eubanks at KRLA, 1964 | birth_name = Robert Leland Eubanks | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1938|1|8|mf=y}} | birth_place = [[Flint, Michigan|Flint]], [[Michigan]], United States | death_date = | death_place = | othername = | occupation = Game show host
Television personality
Radio personality | years_active = 1956–present | spouse = {{marriage|Irma Brown|1969|2002|end=her death}}
Deborah James (2004–present) | children = 4 | homepage = {{URL|bobeubanks.com}} }} '''Robert Leland Eubanks''' (born January 8, 1938) is an American disc jockey, television personality and [[game show host]], best known for hosting the game show ''[[The Newlywed Game]]'' on and off since 1966. He also hosted the successful revamp version of ''[[Card Sharks]]'' from 1986 to 1989.{{cite web |url=http://buzzrplay.com/hosts |title=Hosts |publisher=buzzrplay.com |date=2015|accessdate=May 2, 2016}} Eubanks received a star on the [[Hollywood Walk of Fame]] for his television work in 2000.{{cite web |url=http://projects.latimes.com/hollywood/star-walk/bob-eubanks/ |title=Hollywood Star Walk-Bob Eubanks |work=[[Los Angeles Times]] |date=August 22, 2004 |last=Rasmussen |first=Cynthia |accessdate=March 18, 2011}} The star is in front of [[Grauman's Egyptian Theatre]], where Eubanks worked during the first years of his broadcasting career.{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=yR4qAAAAIBAJ&sjid=--0DAAAAIBAJ&pg=3079,7197264&dq=bob+eubanks&hl=en |title=Eubanks receives star on Walk of Fame |date=December 31, 2000 |newspaper=[[Deseret News]] |accessdate=March 18, 2011}} In 2005, he received a lifetime achievement [[Emmy Award]] from the [[Academy of Television Arts & Sciences]].{{cite web |url=http://articles.latimes.com/2005/jul/07/news/wk-quick7.4 |title=Eubanks to receive award |date=July 7, 2005 |work=[[Los Angeles Times]] |accessdate=March 18, 2011}} ==Biography== Eubanks was born in [[Flint, Michigan]], but was raised primarily in [[Pasadena, California]], where he grew up listening to music, most notably favorites like [[Frank Sinatra]] and [[Doc Watson]]. His parents, John Otho Leland Eubanks (September 28, 1905 – April 11, 1995) and Gertrude Eubanks (née McClure) (February 15, 1907 – July 24, 1997), were originally from [[Missouri]]. They moved to Flint during the [[Great Depression]], where their only child was born, before moving on to California. The young boy became a child model, doing photo shoots for ads and meeting his idol, [[Gene Autry]], when he was scheduled to do an ad photo shoot with him.{{cite book |title=It's In The Book, Bob! |editor-last=Eubanks |editor-first=Bob |editor2-last=Hansen |editor2-first=Matthew Scott |publisher=Benbella Books |page=337 |year=2004 |isbn=978-1-932100-28-0}} He watched popular classic television and quiz game shows. Also growing up in the 1940s and 1950s, he was influenced by [[Cary Grant]], [[Howard Hughes]], [[Buddy Hackett]] and [[Bill Cullen]]. He attended [[Pasadena High School (Pasadena, California)|Pasadena High School]], where he graduated in 1955. After graduation from high school, he attended Pierce College (according to his commentary on a Card Sharks episode) and then went on to become one of California's most popular [[disc jockey]]s. In 1956, his first radio exposure was at [[KVTA|KACY]] Radio in [[Oxnard, California]]. He joined [[KRLA]] in Pasadena in 1960 to do the overnight show. In the spring of 1962 he was promoted to morning drive, then a year later moved to his long-running 6–9 pm evening slot. During most of the 1960s, he was also a producer of concerts, such as [[The Beatles]] 1964 and 1965 [[Hollywood Bowl]] performances,{{cite web |url=http://krlabeat.sakionline.net/issue/9oct64.pdf |title=KRLA Beat |date=October 9, 1964 |publisher=KRLA Radio |accessdate=March 18, 2011}} ([[PDF]]){{cite web |url=http://krlabeat.sakionline.net/issue/12may65.pdf |title=KRLA Beat |date=May 12, 1965 |publisher=KRLA Radio |accessdate=March 18, 2011}} ([[PDF]])and [[The Rolling Stones]], during the first two years of their American tour.{{cite web |url=http://krlabeat.sakionline.net/issue/18nov64.pdf |title=KRLA Beat |date=November 18, 1964 |publisher=KRLA Radio |accessdate=March 18, 2011}} ([[PDF]]) While still in [[Los Angeles]], he also produced such artists as [[Barry Manilow]], [[The Supremes]], [[Dolly Parton]], [[Bob Dylan]], [[Elton John]] and [[Merle Haggard]], among others.{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=P1pGAAAAIBAJ&sjid=cikNAAAAIBAJ&pg=2801,1682131&dq=bob+eubanks&hl=en |title=Famed TV emcee looks ahead to Newburgh Mall festivities |last=Duvoli |first=John |date=March 13, 1980 |newspaper=The Evening News |location=[[Newburgh, New York]] |accessdate=March 18, 2011}} Eubanks married Irma Brown, an avid athlete, ranch forewoman and artist, on September 10, 1969. They had three children: Trace, a retired firefighter; Corey, a stuntman; and Theresa. In 1970, the couple purchased a {{convert|20|acre|m2|adj=on}} portion of a working cattle ranch, and later expanded it to {{convert|26|acres|m2}}. The entire family enjoyed roping and riding, with Eubanks participating in rodeos during his spare time.{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=-6E0AAAAIBAJ&sjid=x60FAAAAIBAJ&pg=3954,3360405&dq=bob+eubanks&hl=en |title=Honeymoon not over for Bob Eubanks |last=White |first=Karen |date=August 14, 1987 |newspaper=[[The Item|The Sumter Daily Item]] |accessdate=March 18, 2011}} Eubanks is a gold card member of the [[Professional Rodeo Cowboys Association]]. Irma handled interior decorating, landscaping, and mounting one to two equestrian shows a year. Irma died in 2002 after a prolonged illness. Around 2004, Eubanks married Deborah James. James is a wedding/events coordinator in Ventura, California and has her own company, Bella Vita Events. The couple has a young son, Noah. In October 2010, Eubanks and his wife put their Westlake Village, CA home on the market.{{cite web |url=http://articles.latimes.com/2010/oct/05/home/la-hm-hotprop-bob-eubanks-20101005 |title=Bob Eubanks lists Westlake Village home |last=Beale |first=Lauren |date=October 5, 2010 |work=Los Angeles Times |accessdate=March 18, 2011}} ==''The Newlywed Game'' and country music business== In 1966, he received a phone call from [[Chuck Barris]] to host a new game show, ''[[The Newlywed Game]]'', which premiered on [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]] that same year. During its debut, it was an immediate hit, and the show's popularity led the network to expand the prime-time lineup, where it had run on the air for five years.{{clarify|date=March 2018}} Only 28 years old when he started hosting, Eubanks became widely popular for bringing a youthful energy to daytime television, pressing contestants into giving embarrassing and hilarious answers. ''The Newlywed Game'' was also ranked as one of the top three daytime game shows, for five consecutive years, between 1968 and 1973, and was ranked in the top three prime-time game shows, also for five years, between 1966 and 1971.{{cite web|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1999/jul/12/news/cl-55088|title=A Talent at Having Fun With the Newly Wed |last=Howe |first=Elena Nelson |date=July 12, 1999 |work=Los Angeles Times |accessdate=March 18, 2011}} While hosting ''The Newlywed Game'', Eubanks was known for using the [[catchphrase]] "makin' whoopee", in reference to marital [[sexual intercourse]]. It was Eubanks who coined the term from the [[Makin' Whoopee|song]] of the same name, in an attempt to keep parents with young children from the need to explain the facts of life because of a television show. While his network was comfortable with the term "making love", they did not allow the use of the word "[[panties]]".{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/01/03/fashion/03night.html?_r=1 |title=The Whoopie Man |last=Diamond |first=Jamie |date=December 31, 2009 |work=[[The New York Times]] |accessdate=March 18, 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5xHaq4gBQ?url=http://www.nytimes.com/2010/01/03/fashion/03night.html?_r=2 |archivedate=March 18, 2011 |deadurl=yes |df=mdy}} While not taping, he also pursued a career in the country music business, where he served as manager of such artists as [[Dolly Parton]], [[Barbara Mandrell]] and [[Marty Robbins]]. The same year, he also signed Merle Haggard to an exclusive live-performance contract, producing more than 100 dates per year with the performer for almost a decade. His first ending of his first-run network TV show, ''The Newlywed Game'', ended in 1974, after 2,195 episodes, making Eubanks one of the most beloved and bankable [[game show hosts]] to date. He also hosted various editions in [[Broadcast syndication|syndication]], from 1977–1980, 1985–1988 and 1997–1999. For Series Two of the 2009 [[Game Show Network|GSN]] revival, Eubanks hosted a celebrity charity episode with first host [[Carnie Wilson]] and her husband [[Rob Bonfiglio]] playing against Carnie's sister [[Wendy Wilson|Wendy]] and her husband Daniel Knutson, and their mother [[Marilyn Wilson-Rutherford]] and her current husband Daniel Rutherford. In spring 2010, Eubanks hosted another episode of ''The Newlywed Game'', subtitled the "Game Show Kings" episode. This episode featured [[Monty Hall]] and his wife Marilyn Hall, [[Peter Marshall (U.S. entertainer)|Peter Marshall]] and his wife Laurie Stewart, and [[Wink Martindale]] with his wife Sandy. This makes him the only person to host the same game show in six consecutive decades (1960s, 1970s, 1980s, 1990s, 2000s and 2010s). In 1988, Eubanks left ''The Newlywed Game'' to pursue other interests (even though he was still hosting ''[[Card Sharks]]'' on CBS for another seven months) and was replaced by [[Paul Rodriguez (actor)|Paul Rodriguez]]. In 1996, Eubanks also appeared as the host of ''Prime Time Country''.{{citation needed|date=March 2015}} ==Other game shows== After ''Newlywed Game'', he hosted a number of other game shows in his career, including ''[[Rhyme and Reason]]'', ''[[Card Sharks]]'', ''[[Dream House (game show)|Dream House]]'', ''[[The Diamond Head Game]]'', ''[[Trivia Trap]]'', and ''[[Powerball: The Game Show]]''.{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=dOYbAAAAIBAJ&sjid=hGgEAAAAIBAJ&pg=4670,7374838&dq=bob+eubanks&hl=en |title=Initial Reaction is Astonishment for Winners on 'Dream House' |last=Scott |first=Vernon |date=September 29, 1983 |work=[[Sarasota Herald-Tribune]] |accessdate=March 18, 2011}}{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=Q_1fAAAAIBAJ&sjid=4AENAAAAIBAJ&pg=1615,2096386&dq=bob+eubanks&hl=en |title=Town woman appears on game show |last=Brewster |first=Sloan |date=May 12, 2001 |work=[[Record-Journal]] |location=[[Meriden, Connecticut]] |accessdate=March 18, 2011}} In 1985, [[Mark Goodson]] hired Eubanks, a second time (the first being the aforementioned [[Trivia Trap]]), to host a revamped version of the show ''[[Card Sharks]]'' for [[CBS]].{{cite web |url=http://articles.latimes.com/1985-11-14/entertainment/ca-2727_1_card-sharks |title='Card Sharks' is Dealt Back In |date=November 14, 1985 |work=Los Angeles Times |accessdate=March 18, 2011}} Eubanks hosted ''Card Sharks'' throughout its CBS run from January 1986 until its demise in March 1989. Prior to hosting ''Card Sharks'', he appeared as a special guest on the original [[NBC]] version alongside [[Jim Perry (television personality)|Jim Perry]] to promote his 1979 game show ''[[All Star Secrets]]'', which he also produced. His final network game show was ''[[Family Secrets (game show)|Family Secrets]]''. In recent years, he has hosted or co-hosted all five of NBC's ''[[Most Outrageous Moments|Most Outrageous Game Show Moments]]'' specials. Eubanks was also one of three rotating hosts (along with [[Chuck Woolery]] and [[Jamie Farr]]) of the "$250,000 Game Show Spectacular" at the [[Las Vegas Hilton]] until the show closed in April 2008.{{cite web |title=R.I.P. $250,000 Game Show Spectacular |url=http://thestrippodcast.blogspot.com/2008/04/rip-250000-game-show-spectacular.html |accessdate=January 1, 2009}} Besides producing Hill-Eubanks's ''All Star Secrets'', the company also produced ''[[The Guinness Game]]'' in 1979–80, ''The [[Toni Tennille]] Show'' in 1980, [[Buddy Hackett]]'s ''[[You Bet Your Life]]'' revival in 1980, and ''Infatuation'' (which Eubanks also hosted) in 1992. Between 1994 and 1995 Eubanks also traveled to [[United Kingdom|Britain]] to host a British version of this series, ''Infatuation UK'', (produced by Thames TV) for UK cable network [[Living (UK TV channel)|Living TV]]. Eubanks tried acting, but found he was not good at doing lines; he also learned the game show business was far more lucrative and less confining.{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=oNMzAAAAIBAJ&sjid=cuYFAAAAIBAJ&pg=5273,5620753&dq=bob+eubanks&hl=en |title=$500,000 For 35 Days' Work |author=Graham, Jefferson |date=May 22, 1988 |newspaper=[[Lawrence Journal-World]] |accessdate=March 18, 2011}}{{cite news |title=Bob Eubanks likes his cake with icing |author=King, Richard |date=July 23, 1983 |newspaper=[[Merced Sun-Star]]}} ==Radio== Prior to entering game shows, Eubanks was a popular radio [[Disc jockey|DJ]] at station [[KRLA 1110]] in Los Angeles as well as a [[music promoter]] and manager, between 1960 and 1968.{{cite web |url=http://articles.latimes.com/2009/oct/04/local/me-then4 |title=In the AM radio wars of the '60s, they talked big and talked back |author=Harvey, Steve |date=October 4, 2009 |work=Los Angeles Times |accessdate=March 18, 2011}} He was responsible for bringing [[The Beatles]] to [[Los Angeles]] for their first West Coast performances in 1964 and 1965 (mortgaging his house to do so),{{cite news |last=Hochman |first=Steve |title=KRLA's Switch to Talk Will End Rock Era on AM Dial in L.A.; Radio Some are nostalgic about a station that retained family appeal to the end. Others say change is overdue. |newspaper=Los Angeles Times |pages=F4 |date=November 16, 1998 |url=https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/latimes/access/36007367.html?dids=36007367:36007367&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&date=Nov+16%2C+1998&author=STEVE+HOCHMAN&pub=Los+Angeles+Times&desc=KRLA's+Switch+to+Talk+Will+End+Rock+Era+on+AM+Dial+in+L.A.%3B+Radio+Some+are+nostalgic+about+a+station+that+retained+family+appeal+to+the+end.+Others+say+change+is+overdue.&pqatl=google}} (pay per view){{cite web |url=http://articles.latimes.com/2004/aug/22/local/me-then22 |title=DJ Mortgaged His House to Bring The Beatles to the Hollywood Bowl |date=August 22, 2004 |author=Rasmussen, Cynthia |work=Los Angeles Times |accessdate=March 18, 2011}} all of which took place at the famed [[Hollywood Bowl]], with fellow KRLA DJs [[Dave Hull]] and Reb Foster joining Eubanks in introducing them. He also operated several [[Cinnamon Cinder chain|Cinnamon Cinder]] nightclubs.{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=8x4rAAAAIBAJ&sjid=xZwFAAAAIBAJ&pg=4061,7705271&dq=bob+eubanks&hl=en |title=Cinnamon Cinder Puts Twinkle in Owner's Eye |author=Thomas, Bob |date=December 31, 1962 |newspaper=[[Reading Eagle]] |accessdate=March 18, 2011}} In the early to mid 1960s, the house band at his the Traffic Circle Cinnamon Cinder club was [[The Vibrants (Californian band)|The Vibrants]].{{cite news |work=[[Long Beach Independent]] |date=December 13, 1963 |url=https://www.newspapers.com/newspage/22874771/ |title=Kerplunk! He Got Stuck in Mud |first=Tedd |last=Thomey |subscription=yes}} He stood in for [[Casey Kasem]] twice on radio's ''[[American Top 40]]'': January 9–10, 1982 (that year's first regular episode), and April 16–17, 1983. ==Other appearances== In 1992, Eubanks appeared on the TV sitcom ''[[The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air]]'' in the episode "Eyes on the Prize" hosting the game show "Double Trouble." That same year, he also made a cameo in the movie ''[[Home Alone 2: Lost in New York]]'' hosting the game show "Ding-Dang-Dong", where he mentioned that the show's contestants stayed at the [[Plaza Hotel]] in [[New York City]], and also gave the phone number for reservations (which allowed [[Kevin McCallister]], played by [[Macaulay Culkin]], to check in). He has also hosted the [[Tournament of Roses Parade]] on Los Angeles television channel [[KTLA]] since 1976 and with [[Stephanie Edwards (TV personality)|Stephanie Edwards]] from 1978–2005. In 2006, Eubanks continued to host with Edwards's replacement, [[KTLA Morning Show]] anchor [[Michaela Pereira]]. Edwards returned to her co-hosting position alongside Eubanks in 2009.{{cite web|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2009/jan/02/nation/na-onthemedia2|title=Stephanie Edwards returns to her lofty perch|author=Rainey, James|date=January 2, 2009|work=Los Angeles Times|accessdate=March 18, 2011}} In September 2015, Bob Eubanks and Stephanie Edwards announced on the KTLA Morning News that the 2016 parade will be their last.{{cite web |author=Sam Rubin |url=http://ktla.com/2015/09/25/world-exclusive-stephanie-edwards-and-bob-eubanks-make-a-big-announcement-its-just-time/ |title=World Exclusive: Stephanie Edwards and Bob Eubanks Make a Big Announcement: ‘It’s Just Time’ |website=Ktla.com |date=2015-09-25 |accessdate=2016-12-27}} In 2017, they were replaced by [[Leeza Gibbons]] and [[Mark Steines]]. Eubanks appeared as himself on the [[Nickelodeon]] sitcom ''[[Kenan & Kel]]'' in the episode "[[List of Kenan & Kel episodes|The Honeymoon's Over]]", which aired May 1999. He guest-starred on ''[[That '70s Show]]'' in the January 2000 episode "Eric's Stash". He also hosted the some years the [[Miss California USA]] Pageant and [[Mrs. International Pageant]], sister pageant to the Miss International (United States) Pageant, between 2000 and 2003.{{cite web |url=http://www.pageantrymagazine.com/magazine/features/2001/d01/d01mrsintlwebed.html |title=Mrs. International Pageant: The Honeymoon Continues |work=Pageantry |accessdate=August 11, 2013}} On July 6, 2007, Eubanks sat in as a celebrity "Mob Member" on the NBC [[game show]] ''[[1 vs. 100 (U.S. game show)|1 vs. 100]]''. A year after that, he appeared as a ''[[GSN Live]]'' guest on April 4, 2008 and returned on May 18, 2010. His most recent television appearance (not counting his annual KTLA Rose Parade appearances) was on ''[[The Amazing Race 17]]'' season finale, which aired December 12, 2010. In 2011, Eubanks hosted a special version of ''The Newlywed Game'', live at Champion's Week for the ''[[NASCAR]]'' ''[[Sprint Cup Series]]''. His [[autobiography]], ''It's in the Book, Bob'' ({{ISBN|1-932100-28-8}}), was published in 2004. Eubanks briefly appears in the music video for [[The Offspring]]'s "[[Why Don't You Get a Job?]]"{{YouTube|yR6A-Bk9eZQ|"Why Don't You Get A Job?"}} In 2013, Eubanks toured with "America's Greatest Game Shows: Live on Stage".{{citation needed|date=January 2014}} In 2015, he appeared as a host of a couples game on Marriage Boot Camp: Reality Stars (WE channel). ==Controversy== He appeared in [[Michael Moore]]'s 1989 documentary ''[[Roger & Me]]''. The film documented Moore's attempts to track [[General Motors]] [[Chief executive officer|CEO]] [[Roger Smith (executive)|Roger Smith]] to confront him about the company's impact on Flint, Michigan and Moore's claim that it was responsible for massive [[Layoff|downsizing]].{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=EElOAAAAIBAJ&sjid=8hMEAAAAIBAJ&pg=7059,5746917&dq=bob+eubanks&hl=en |title='Roger & Me' part of savagely funny film tradition |author=Wiley, Mason |date=June 30, 1980 |newspaper=[[Star-News]] |location=Wilmington, NC |accessdate=March 18, 2011}} Eubanks, a native of Flint, was interviewed about his views on the downsizing, and was filmed reciting an [[Off-color humor|off-color]] joke about AIDS: {{ quote|MOORE: [In regards to ''The Newlywed Game'' containing racy/sexual content] Bob was right. He didn't say "breasts" and I considered apologizing for implying that his show wasn't wholesome family entertainment. [cut to:] EUBANKS: You know why Jewish women don't get AIDS? Because they marry assholes, they don't screw them. Pardon me.{{cite web |url=http://www.script-o-rama.com/movie_scripts/r/roger-and-me-script-transcript.html |title=Roger And Me Script - transcript from the screenplay and/or Michael Moore movie |website=Script-o-rama.com |date= |accessdate=2016-12-27}} }} According to Moore in the film's DVD commentary, Eubanks attempted to denounce the film with the [[Anti-Defamation League]] for containing anti-Semitic content, despite the fact that he himself contributed the sole moment of anti-Semitic content present in the film. ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== * {{IMDb name|0262275}} * [https://web.archive.org/web/20100111113327/http://www.worldpokertour.com/Shared/Players/Bios/B/Bob_Eubanks.aspx World Poker Tour Profile] * {{EmmyTVLegends name|bob-eubanks|Bob Eubanks}} {{s-start}} {{s-media}} {{succession box | before = [[Jim Perry (television personality)|Jim Perry]] | title = Host of [[Card Sharks]] | years = January 6, 1986 – March 31, 1989| after = [[Pat Bullard]]}} {{s-end}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Eubanks, Bob}} [[Category:1938 births]] [[Category:American radio DJs]] [[Category:American game show hosts]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:People from Flint, Michigan]] [[Category:People from the Greater Los Angeles Area]] [[Category:Beauty pageant hosts]]

{{update|date=August 2018}} {{Infobox rugby union season | name = Border Region: Schools & Youth Competitions | image = | imagesize = | caption = | countries = [[Scotland]] and [[England]] | date = September – December 2015 | champions = | count = | runnersup = | promoted = | relegated = | matches = | attendance = | tries = | top point scorer = | top try scorer = | prevseason = | nextseason = }} The '''Border Region: Schools & Youth Competitions''' structures established for the 2015-16 season group schools and clubs based on the development structures they have in place, the volume of teams they operate and results over recent seasons. The fixture programmes arranged by Scottish Rugby will guarantee blocks of 'school v school' or 'club v club' fixtures in the autumn phase of the seasonhttp://www.scottishrugby.org/fixtures-results-schools-youth ==History== In December 2013 Scottish Rugby launched its strategic initiative ‘Youth Rugby – A Strategy for Schools’.http://www.scottishrugbyforum.org/wp-content/wps-content/forum/735/795/1_sr_clubyouth_updateapril2015.pdf Former [[Scotland national rugby union team|Scotland]] rugby coach [[Frank Hadden]] conducted the review for [[Scottish Rugby]].http://www.heraldscotland.com/sport/rugby/onus-on-scottish-rugby-to-stop-gold-spoon-from-devouring-schools-scene.121974225 "In recent years youth rugby has had many changes in competition structure mainly based on the needs and wants of participating teams, some teams have thrived, some teams have struggled but change has been a constant and it is obvious that the current structure continues to be affected by; withdrawal of teams from leagues, weather, lack of competitive fixtures for some teams, a disjointed approach to fixturing, a reluctance by some to play on a regular basis. There is no doubt that the structure for youth rugby has reached a point where a radical change in approach is required to bring stability to our game."http://www.scottishrugbyforum.org/wp-content/wps-content/forum/735/795/1_sr_clubyouth_updateapril2015.pdf ==Format== '''U18''' Border Semi Junior League - Clubs '''U16''' Border U16 League - Clubs '''S3 (U15)''' - Schools '''S2 (U14)''' - Schools '''S1 (U13)''' - Schools ==Leagues== ===Border Semi-Junior League=== [http://www.scottishrugby.org/fixtures-results/?competition=106260 ''Fixtures, results and tables for the Border Semi-Junior League''] - Two teams are based in [[Northumberland]], [[England]] - [[Berwick RFC|Berwick Colts]] and [[Tynedale RFC]] {{col-begin|width=95%}} {{col-break|width=66%}} {| class="wikitable sortable" style="text-align:left; line-height:110%; font-size:100%; width:95%;" |- | colspan=4 align=center style="background-color:#ffffff;color:#BE2625" | '''2015 Border Semi-Junior League''' |- ! width="40%" | Team ! width="30%" | Location |- | [[Berwick RFC|Berwick Colts]] || [[Berwick-upon-Tweed]], [[Northumberland]] |- | [[Duns RFC|Duns Colts]] || [[Duns]] |- | [[Gala Wanderers]] || [[Galashiels]] |- | [[Hawick Wanderers]] || [[Hawick]] |- | [[Hawick PSA]] || [[Hawick]] |- | [[Jed Thistle RFC|Jed Thistle]] || [[Jedburgh]] |- | [[Kelso RFC|Kelso Harlequins]] || [[Kelso,_Scottish_Borders|Kelso]] |- | [[Melrose RFC|Melrose Wasps]] || [[Melrose,_Scottish_Borders|Melrose]] |- | [[Peebles RFC|Peebles Colts]] || [[Peebles]] |- | [[Selkirk Youth RFC|Selkirk YC]] || [[Selkirk,_Scottish_Borders|Selkirk]] |- | [[Tynedale RFC|Tynedale Colts]] || [[Corbridge]], [[Northumberland]] |} {| class="wikitable sortable" style="text-align:left; line-height:110%; font-size:100%; width:60%;" |- | colspan=4 align=center style="background-color:#ffffff;color:#BE2625" | '''Border Semi Junior League Winners Table''' |- ! revision.text:
{{Infobox professional wrestler | name = Chris Markoff | birthname = | image = | caption = | names = Chris Jelevarov
Chris Jelevorou
Chris Markoff
Chris Markov
Chris Zeleurov
Harry Madison | height = {{height|ft=6|in=0}} | weight = {{convert|275|lb|kg st|abbr=on}} | birth_date = | birth_place = [[Yugoslavia]] | resides = | billed = [[Socialist Republic of Macedonia|Macedonia]]
[[Socialist Republic of Serbia|Serbia]]
[[Russian Soviet Federative Socialist Republic|Russia]] | trainer = | debut = 1960s | retired = 1980s }} '''Chris Markoff''' is a Yugoslavian/American retired [[Professional wrestling|professional wrestler]]. He is best known for his appearances with [[professional wrestling promotion]]s in the [[Midwestern United States]] in the 1960s.{{cite book|author=Kristian Pope|title=Tuff Stuff Professional Wrestling Field Guide: Legend and Lore|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=jcRlZN7dIP0C&pg=PA294|date=14 August 2005|publisher=Krause Publications|isbn=1-4402-2810-8|pages=294}}{{cite web|url=https://www.cagematch.net/?id=2&nr=1993|title=Chris Markoff|work=Cagematch.de|accessdate=September 30, 2017}}{{cite book|author=Dale Pierce|title=Wrestling in Akron|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=IqFpBgAAQBAJ&pg=PA75|date=10 June 2013|publisher=Arcadia Publishing Incorporated|isbn=978-1-4396-4350-1|pages=75}} ==Early life== Markoff was born in [[Yugoslavia]] and raised in [[Minneapolis]], [[Minnesota]] in the United States.{{cite book|author1=[[Harley Race]]|author2=Gerry Tritz|title=King of the Ring: The Harley Race Story|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=yKlr1fZuWIEC&pg=PA31|year=2004|publisher=Sports Publishing LLC|isbn=978-1-58261-818-0|pages=31}} ==Professional wrestling career== Markoff began his career in the Minneapolis-based [[American Wrestling Association]] in the mid-1960s.{{cite web|url=https://www.cagematch.net/?id=2&nr=1993&page=20|title=Chris Markoff – Career|work=Cagematch.de|accessdate=September 30, 2017}} Managed by Professor Steve Druk, he feuded with [[The Crusher (wrestler)|The Crusher]]. He became [[AWA World Tag Team Championship|AWA World Tag Team Champion]] with [[Harley Race]] in January 1967 after Race's original partner, [[Larry Hennig]], sustained a broken leg. Their reign ended in November 1967 when they were defeated by [[Pat O'Connor (wrestler)|Pat O'Connor]] and [[Wilbur Snyder]].{{cite web|url=https://www.cagematch.net/?id=2&nr=1993&page=11|title=Chris Markoff – Titles|work=Cagematch.de|accessdate=September 30, 2017}} In the mid-1960s, Markoff began wrestling for the [[Indianapolis]], [[Indiana]]-based [[World Wrestling Association (Indianapolis)|World Wrestling Association]], where he formed a [[tag team]] with [[Angelo Poffo]] called "The Devil's Duo". Markoff and Poffo won the [[WWA World Tag Team Championship]] in 1966 and again in 1967.{{cite book|author=Harris M. Lentz III|title=Obituaries in the Performing Arts, 2010|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=LH_GCwAAQBAJ&pg=PA338|date=9 May 2011|publisher=McFarland|isbn=978-0-7864-4175-4|pages=338}} In the late-1960s, Markoff began competing for [[Championship Wrestling from Florida]]. He won the [[NWA Florida Tag Team Championship]] in 1969 and again in 1972. In 1969, Markoff wrestled for the [[Los Angeles]], [[California]]-based promotion [[NWA Hollywood Wrestling]]. Over the course of the year, he won the [[NWA Americas Tag Team Championship]] with Bronko Lubich, the [[NWA "Beat the Champ" Television Championship]], and the NWA Pacific Coast Heavyweight Championship ''(Los Angeles version)'' three times. In 1972, Markoff toured Japan with the [[Japan Pro Wrestling Alliance|Japan Wrestling Association]], wrestling a series of matches against [[Apache Bull Ramos]]. Antagonism between Markoff and Ramos resulted in a legitimate brawl in a restaurant during which Ramos bit off part of Markoff's ear and Markoff bit off the tip of Ramos' finger.{{cite book|author1=Jim Wilson|author2=Jim Wilson & Weldon T. Johnson|title=Chokehold: Pro Wrestling's Real Mayhem Outside the Ring|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=epCYZj7Li-AC&pg=PA117|date=2 September 2003|publisher=Xlibris Corporation|isbn=978-1-4628-1172-4|pages=117}} In 1978, Markoff wrestled in New Zealand for All Star Pro Wrestling, briefly holding the [[NWA British Empire/Commonwealth Championship]]. In the same year, he wrestled in [[Hawaii]] for [[50th State Big Time Wrestling]], holding the [[NWA Hawaii Tag Team Championship]] with [[Steve DiSalvo|Steve Strong]]. In 1981, Markoff joined the [[Charlotte, North Carolina]]-based [[Jim Crockett Promotions]], where he formed a tag team with [[Nikolai Volkoff]] called "The Imperial Russians". Managed by [[Lord Alfred Hayes]], the duo won the [[NWA Mid-Atlantic Tag Team Championship]] later that year.{{cite book|author=Harris M. Lentz III|title=Obituaries in the Performing Arts, 2005: Film, Television, Radio, Theatre, Dance, Music, Cartoons and Pop Culture|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=_nvGCwAAQBAJ&pg=PA164|date=4 May 2006|publisher=McFarland|isbn=978-0-7864-5210-1|pages=164}} ==Championships and accomplishments== *'''[[50th State Big Time Wrestling]]''' **[[NWA Hawaii Tag Team Championship]] (1 time) – with [[Stephen Cepello|Steve Strong]] *'''[[American Wrestling Association]]''' **[[AWA World Tag Team Championship]] (1 time) – with [[Harley Race]] *'''[[Championship Wrestling from Florida]]''' **[[NWA Florida Tag Team Championship]] (2 times) – with [[Bronko Lubich]] (1 time) and [[Bobby Shane]] (1 time){{cite book|author=Harris M. Lentz III|title=Obituaries in the Performing Arts, 2007: Film, Television, Radio, Theatre, Dance, Music, Cartoons and Pop Culture|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=AX3GCwAAQBAJ&pg=PA226|date=20 May 2008|publisher=McFarland|isbn=978-0-7864-5191-3|pages=226}} *'''[[Jim Crockett Promotions]]''' **[[NWA Mid-Atlantic Tag Team Championship]] (1 time) – with [[Nikolai Volkoff]]{{cite book|author1=[[The Missing Link (wrestler)|Dewey Robertson]]|author2=Meredith Renwick|title=Bang Your Head: The Real Story of the Missing Link|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=rjzJVTkRypoC&pg=PA86|year=2006|publisher=ECW Press|isbn=978-1-55022-727-7|pages=86}} *'''[[World Class Championship Wrestling#Big Time Wrestling: 1966-81|NWA Big Time Wrestling]]''' **[[WCWA World Tag Team Championship|NWA American Tag Team Championship]] (1 time) – with Bronko Lubich **[[NWA Brass Knuckles Championship]] (1 time) *'''[[NWA Detroit]]''' **[[NWA World Tag Team Championship (Detroit version)|NWA World Tag Team Championship]] (1 time) – with [[Dominic DeNucci]] *'''[[NWA Hollywood Wrestling]]''' **[[NWA Americas Tag Team Championship]] (1 time) – with Bronko Lubich ** [[NWA "Beat the Champ" Television Championship]] ([[NWA "Beat the Champ" Television Championship#Title history|1 time]]){{cite web|url=http://www.wrestling-titles.com/us/ca/la/nwa/int-tv.html|title=N.W.A. "Beat the Champ" International Television Title (Los Angeles)|year=2003|publisher=Puroresu Dojo}} ** NWA Pacific Coast Heavyweight Championship ''(Los Angeles version)'' (3 times){{cite web|url=http://www.wrestling-titles.com/us/ca/s/la-pc-h.html|title=Pacific Coast Heavyweight Title (Los Angeles)|year=2017|publisher=Wrestling-Titles.com|accessdate=October 1, 2017}} *'''[[National Wrestling Alliance|NWA]] New Zealand''' **[[NWA British Empire/Commonwealth Championship (New Zealand version)]] (1 time) *'''[[World Wrestling Association (Indianapolis)|World Wrestling Association]]''' **[[WWA World Tag Team Championship]] (2 times) – with [[Angelo Poffo]]{{cite book|author=Harris M. Lentz III|title=Obituaries in the Performing Arts, 2010|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=LH_GCwAAQBAJ&pg=PA338|date=9 May 2011|publisher=McFarland|isbn=978-0-7864-4175-4|pages=338}}{{cite book|author=George Schire|title=Minnesota's Golden Age of Wrestling: From Verne Gagne to the Road Warriors|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=r8PjMDAUwSAC&pg=PA222|year=2010|publisher=Minnesota Historical Society|isbn=978-0-87351-620-4|pages=222}} ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==External links== {{Portal|Professional wrestling}} * {{Professional wrestling profiles}} {{NWA World Tag Team Champions (Detroit version)}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Markoff, Chris}} [[Category:American male professional wrestlers]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Professional wrestlers from Minnesota]] [[Category:Yugoslav emigrants to the United States]] [[Category:Yugoslav professional wrestlers]] [[ja:クリス・マルコフ]]

The '''''Class sketch''''' is a [[comedy sketch]] first broadcast in an episode of [[David Frost]]'s satirical comedy programme ''[[The Frost Report]]'' on 7 April 1966.<ref>{{IMDb title|1150598}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.uknowotimean.com/funny-stuff/top-25-sketches/cleese-barker-corbett/|title=John Cleese, Ronnie Barker, and Ronnie Corbett, I Know My Place |publisher=www.uknowotimean.com |accessdate=2012-11-24 }}</ref> It has been described as a "genuinely timeless sketch, ingeniously satirising the [[Social structure of the United Kingdom|British class system]]"<ref name = BFI>{{cite web |url=http://www.screenonline.org.uk/tv/id/852164/ |title=BFI Screenonline: Frost Report, The (1966–67) |publisher=[[British Film Institute]] |accessdate=2010-04-21 }}</ref> and in 2005 was voted number 40 in [[Channel Four]]'s "Britain's 50 Greatest Comedy Sketches".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.comedy.co.uk/news/old_story/278/ |title=BBC4 to celebrate The Frost Report |publisher=www.comedy.co.uk |accessdate=2010-04-21 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.channel4.com/entertainment/tv/microsites/G/greatest/comedy_sketches/results.html |title=Channel4 – 50 Greatest Comedy Sketches |publisher=www.channel4.com |accessdate=2010-04-21 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100327141914/http://www.channel4.com/entertainment/tv/microsites/G/greatest/comedy_sketches/results.html |archivedate=March 27, 2010 }}</ref> It was written by [[Marty Feldman]] and [[John Law (writer)|John Law]],<ref name = TVH>{{cite web |url=http://www.televisionheaven.co.uk/shows_fi_to_fu.htm#frost_report |title=THE FROST REPORT – A TELEVISION HEAVEN REVIEW |publisher=www.televisionheaven.co.uk |accessdate=2014-05-18 }}</ref> and features [[John Cleese]], [[Ronnie Barker]], and [[Ronnie Corbett]].
==Synopsis== [[File:FrostReportClassSketch.jpg|thumb|Cleese, Barker, and Corbett in the sketch as broadcast in April 1966]]
Cleese, tall and [[Elitism|patrician]] in appearance and demeanour, represents the [[upper class]]; Barker, of average height, the [[middle class]], and Corbett, short in stature, the [[working class]]. Each in turn describes their social advantages and disadvantages, and contrasts them with their neighbours, an effect emphasised by the actors' relative heights as they look downwards or upwards to each other: {{quote|Barker: "I look up to him [Cleese] because he is upper class, but I look down on him [Corbett] because he is lower class." Corbett: "I know my place."<ref name = TVH/>}}
It is this situation that gives Corbett the [[Punch line|pay-off line]]; as the others describe their advantages in the form of "I get ... (e.g. a sense of superiority)", his character finally looks up at the others and says "I get a pain in the back of my neck."<ref name = BBC>{{cite web |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/comedy/thefrostreport/ |title=BBC – Comedy – The Frost Report |publisher=BBC.co.uk |accessdate=2010-04-21 }}</ref>
==Reception and influence== The [[British Film Institute]] commented, "Its twinning of height and social position, combined with a minimal script, created a classic TV moment."<ref name = BFI/> The sketch's influence has persisted to the present day, having been referred to in 21st-century discussions of politics,<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/1552095/Theres-no-way-up.html |title=There's no way up – Telegraph |work=[[Daily Telegraph]]|accessdate=2010-04-21 |location=London |date=2007-05-20}}</ref> sociology,<ref>{{cite book |last= Braham|first= Peter|author2=Linda Janes|year= 2002|publisher= Blackwell|isbn= 978-0-631-23310-7|page= 62|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=j9rqacodOaAC&pg=PA62&lpg=PA62&dq=the+frost+report+an+understanding+of+class&source=bl&ots=jURNHhCpTA&sig=ihjcwImaeQRlcV_5Zgf4Lk5mJ-4&hl=en&ei=HTDPS6LCD82tsAbez725Aw&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=6&ved=0CBMQ6AEwBTgU#v=onepage&q&f=false |title=Social differences and divisions|accessdate=2010-04-21}}</ref> and even football.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2009/jul/30/marina-hyde-manchester-city-united |title=Sir Alex's nod to Nancy Mitford | author=Marina Hyde |work=Guardian.co.uk |accessdate=2010-04-21 | location=London | date=2009-07-30}}</ref>
==Spinoffs== Ronnie Barker wrote scripts for three further "Three Classes" sketches featuring the same characters, comparing their family life, their leisure activities, and their work.<ref>{{cite book |title=All I Ever Wrote |last=Barker |first=Ronnie |isbn=9780283073342 |page=42}}</ref>
A spinoff sketch was broadcast on the BBC Millennium programme,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0JSahEDRjvw|title=The Two Ronnies - 2000 Today|author=ratpackmanreturns|date=15 December 2007|publisher=|via=YouTube}}</ref> satirising three eras of English history. [[Stephen Fry]] represents Modern Man, Barker a [[miller]] from the [[English Renaissance|Renaissance]], and Corbett a weaver serf from the [[Middle Ages]]. The basic premise of the sketch is no different from the original. The sketch was incorporated into ''[[The Nearly Complete and Utter History of Everything]]''.
==Copyright==
The estates of Marty Feldman and John Law have apparently being aggressively pursuing copyright on the sketch which makes it difficult to access today.
==References== {{Reflist|colwidth=33em}}
[[Category:British comedy]] [[Category:Comedy sketches]] [[Category:1966 in British television]]

revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=May 2015}} {{Infobox television |show_name = Clifford's Puppy Days |image = Clifford Puppy Days.gif |caption = |director = Bob Doucette |alt = A smiling red puppy, Clifford, sits above a rectangle containing the name of the series in stylized text. |runtime = 25 minutes |company = [[Scholastic Corporation|Scholastic Entertainment]]
[[Mike Young Productions]] |distributor = [[Lionsgate]] |creator = [[Norman Bridwell]] (characters) |language = English |voices = [[Lara Jill Miller]]
[[Grey DeLisle]]
[[Cam Clarke]]
[[Kath Soucie]]
[[Masiela Lusha]]
[[Orlando Brown (actor)|Orlando Brown]]
[[LaTonya Holmes]]
[[Ogie Banks]]
[[Jess Harnell]]
[[Lauren Tom]]
[[Henry Winkler]]
[[Candi Milo]] |genre = |theme_music_composer = [[Jared Faber]]
[[Emily Kapnek]] |opentheme = "Love Makes Little Things Grow" by [[Freedom Bremner]] |endtheme = "Love Makes Little Things Grow" (Instrumental) |composer = Jared Faber |country = United States |network = [[PBS]]
[[PBS Kids]] |num_seasons = 2 |num_episodes = 39 (78 Segments) |first_aired = {{Start date|2003|9|15}} |last_aired = {{End date|2006|2|23}} |preceded_by = ''[[Clifford the Big Red Dog (TV series)|Clifford the Big Red Dog]]'' }} '''''Clifford's Puppy Days''''' is an American [[animated television series|animated]] [[children's television series]] that originally aired on both [[PBS]] and [[PBS Kids]] from September 15, 2003 to February 23, 2006.{{cite web|title=Clifford's Puppy Days Volume 3|url=https://www.amazon.com/gp/aw/d/B00X4S9SJY|publisher=Amazon.com|accessdate=February 17, 2017}} A prequel to the original ''[[Clifford the Big Red Dog (TV series)|Clifford the Big Red Dog]]'', it features the adventures of Clifford during his puppy days before he became a big red dog and before moving to Birdwell Island. The series was cancelled in February 2006 following low ratings,{{citation needed|date=March 2015}} with very few PBS stations re-running it afterwards. Since then, occasional reruns continue to air. In the UK the show aired on [[CBeebies]] from 2004 to early 2011 and like the original series, the show was dubbed with British voice actors, replacing the original American soundtrack. ==Setting== Set two years before the events of ''[[Clifford the Big Red Dog]]'', the series focuses on when Clifford is a tiny red puppy, the runt of the litter in a litter of puppies given birth to by the pet dog of Emily Elizabeth's neighbor, Mr. Bradley (who appeared in an episode of the first cartoon series, "Little Clifford") and after he had been adopted by Emily Elizabeth and before he grew up into a giant red adult dog, forcing the Howards to move to Birdwell Island so Clifford would have plenty of room, the series shows Clifford and Emily Elizabeth's life and friends before they moved from the city to Birdwell Island and all of their adventures. ==Format== The show followed the same format as its predecessor, ''[[Clifford the Big Red Dog (TV series)|Clifford the Big Red Dog]]''. *The opening theme is followed by the first central story, which is about the dogs, and a problem they face. *Storytime with Speckle – Between the first and second story, Emily Elizabeth reads Clifford the Speckle Story, a small 60 seconds (approximately) time filler about a fictional dog (Speckle), and his animal friends. *This is followed by another central story, about Emily Elizabeth and her friends. *Clifford's Idea to Grow On – Before the credits, another 30-second short takes place called Clifford's Idea to Grow On. The short is basically an animation of an etiquette, a proverb, or basic truth such as "Play Fair", "Help Others", etc., with narration by Emily Elizabeth. This short was called Clifford's Big Idea in the previous series. ==Characters== *'''Clifford''' (voiced by [[Lara Jill Miller]]; Lizzie Waterworth in the British version as a puppy) – Pet number 2 (but dog number 1) of Emily Elizabeth. A small puppy who is highly playful and always looks forward to meet new friends. He loves to play with his toys, eat dog treats, and like Daffodil he loves to take naps. His best friend is Jorge and his older sister is Daffodil (who is a rabbit), who cares very deeply for him. *'''Emily Elizabeth Howard''' (voiced by [[Grey DeLisle]]; [[Joanna Ruiz]] in the British version) – The affectionate 8-year-old owner of Clifford and Daffodil. Her best friend is Nina. *'''Daffodil''' (voiced by [[Kath Soucie]]) – A [[Holland Lop]], pet number 1 of Emily Elizabeth, and also Clifford's helper, protector, and sister. She is portrayed as a very neat rabbit. She loves to take walks, take naps, eat carrots, and play with Clifford and her toys. Her catchphrase is "Sure I'm sure". She sometimes gets annoyed by Clifford, but whenever Clifford is crying, scared, needs help, or just feels alone, she is always there for him. In the first half of the series she was originally pink but her fur was changed to white in the second half. *'''Nina''' (voiced by [[Masiela Lusha]]) – is the sweet and enthusiastic owner of Jorge. Her best friend is Emily Elizabeth. Sometimes, however, Nina is shown to be insensitive to others' feelings, which causes rifts between her and her friends, although they always make up in the end. *'''Evan Thomas Taylor''' (voiced by [[Orlando Brown (actor)|Orlando Brown]]) – A boy who looks a few years older than Emily Elizabeth but nevertheless one of her best friends. He loves to play basketball. He is also a great skater and Emily learned how to skate from him. *'''Shun''' (voiced by [[Lauren Tom]]; [[Ben Small|Benjamin Small]] in the British version) – A young Japanese-American boy who is quiet, intelligent, and very proud of his Japanese heritage. He is a very close friend of Emily Elizabeth and Nina. Although he is not good at sports, he is always willing to give new things a try. *'''Flo and Zo''' (voiced by LaTonya Holmes and [[Ogie Banks]], respectively) – Brother and sister, but twins of kittens who are very playful. They usually love to play with each other or play with their other friends. They are owned by Mr. Solomon. In the episodes "The Big, Big Present/Hanukkah Plunder Blunder," it is revealed that they and Mr. Solomon are Jewish. *'''Jorge/George (UK)''' (voiced by [[Jess Harnell]]; [[Ben Small|Benjamin Small]] in the British version) – A brown [[dachshund]] who loves to have fun with his best friend, Clifford. His owner is Nina. *'''Norville''' (voiced by [[Henry Winkler]]; Tom Eastwood in the British version) – A bird who always has problems. He often calls Clifford "little red" or "pup". *'''Mr. Solomon''' (voiced by [[Alan Oppenheimer]]) – A wheelchair-bound writer. Flo and Zo are his two pet kittens. In the episodes "The Big, Big Present/Hanukkah Plunder Blunder," it is revealed that he, Flo, and Zo are Jewish. *'''The Sidarskis''' – A family of mice who live in the laundromat. They have five playful children, Lucy, Lewis, Sophie, Sid, and a new baby. *'''Tricksie''' (voiced by [[Russi Taylor]]) - An elderly dog who once performed in the circus with her owner, Mrs. Z. She has little interaction with Clifford and his friends, but is still very friendly to them. *'''Mrs. Z''' - An elderly Italian woman who was once in the circus, and Trixie's owner. She is shown to be quite kind towards the kids. *'''Bebe''' (voiced by [[Jill Talley]]) – A [[Golden Retriever]] [[Guide dog|Seeing-eye dog]], who joins in on Clifford and his friends' fun whenever she can spare the time. She belongs to a blind girl named Jenny. *'''Jenny''' (voiced by Dionne Quan) - A blind girl and Bebe's owner. While she is blind, Jenny has unusually high situational awareness, being able to tell where things are without even touching them. She demonstrates expertise in botany and gardening, helping the kids to plant a willow tree. ==Stories== Each half-hour episode was divided into 2 stories. '''Season 1''' #Keeping Cool / Socks & Snooze #The Monster in 3-B / Cat-tastrophe #Jorge and the Dog Run / Clifford's Clubhouse #Paw Print Picasso / Hup Hup #Sock It to Me / My Toy #Friends of All Ages / Clifford's Super Sleepover #Clifford's Field Trip / Helping Paws #Nina's Perfect Party / Just the Right Size #Something Special / Shun Gets in the Game #Clifford's Winter Spirit / Flo-Motion #No Small Parts, Only Small Puppies / Fine Feather Friend #Sing-a-Song Norville / Tell Me a Tale #Hoop Dreams / Doggie Duds #The Best Nest / Practice Makes Perfect #Your Secret Valentine / Perfect Pet #My Blanky / With Friends Like You #Time Out / Sniff, Sniff #A Promise Is a Promise / Share and Share Alike #Fall Feast / Norville's New Game #Oh, Brother / Up, Up, & Oops! #Moving On / Fair Is Fair #Grooming Gloom / The Letter #Adopt-a-Pup / Jokes on You #Lights, Camera, Action / Basketball Babysitter #The Halloween Bandit / An Honest Spin '''Season 2''' #Puppy Dog Power / Extra! Extra! #Small Packages / Clifford's Magic Lamp #Finders Keepers / You're Famous #Sandcastle Hassle / School Daze #Celebrating Spring / Garden Delights #Clifford the Scary Puppy / Things That Go Bump #The Big Surprise / Be My Guest #But I Really, Really Saw It! / The Perfect Pancake #Clifford's Little Friend / Tricky Business #The Big, Big Present / Hanukkah Plunder Blunder #Show and Tell / What a Story #Heroes and Friends / The Cookie Crumbles #Lost and Found / Basketball Blunders #Valentine Schmalentine / Sweethearts Dance ==Broadcast== After the show's cancellation in 2006, the show aired reruns on very few PBS stations. However, it airs occasionally on the new 24/7 PBS Kids Channel, which is carried on many PBS member stations. ==Opening theme== The opening theme, "Love Makes Little Things Grow", was composed by [[Jared Faber]] and [[Emily Kapnek]] and performed by Freedom Bremner.{{cite web|title=Clifford's Puppy Days™ Theme Song|url=http://pbskids.org/clifford/puppydays/puppy_quicktime.html|publisher=PBS Kids|accessdate=May 25, 2017}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *{{IMDb title|377156}} *{{tv.com show|cliffords-puppy-days}} *[http://pbskids.org/clifford/puppydays/ ''Clifford's Puppy Days''] at [[PBS Kids]] {{Clifford the Big Red Dog}} {{PBSKids shows}} [[Category:2000s American animated television series]] [[Category:2003 American television series debuts]] [[Category:2006 American television series endings]] [[Category:BBC children's television programmes]] [[Category:Child versions of cartoon characters]] [[Category:PBS network shows]] [[Category:Television shows set in New York City]] [[Category:Preschool education television series]] [[Category:Prequel television series]] [[Category:Television shows about dogs]] [[Category:American animated television programs featuring anthropomorphic characters]] [[Category:Television programs based on children's books]] [[Category:Television series about friendship]] [[Category:PBS Kids shows]] [[Category:American children's animated comedy television series]]

{{Distinguish|Cascading Style Sheets}} {{Infobox encryption method |name = Content Scramble System (CSS) |designers = [[DVD Forum]] |publish date = 1996 |series = |derived from = |related to = |certification = [[DVD Copy Control Association]] |key size = [[40-bit encryption|40 bits]] |block size = |security claim = 2<sup>40</sup> |state size = 2048 bytes (DVD [[Disk sector|sector]] size) |structure = [[Stream cipher]] |rounds = |speed = |cryptanalysis = Defeated in 1999 by [[DeCSS]], [[40-bit encryption|40-bit key size]] is subject to [[brute-force attack]], effective key size is about 16 bits. This can be brute-forced in about a minute by a [[Pentium II]], or a few seconds by a modern CPU. }}
The '''Content Scramble System''' ('''CSS''') is a [[digital rights management]] (DRM) and [[encryption]] system employed on many commercially produced [[DVD-Video]] discs. CSS utilizes a [[wikt:proprietary|proprietary]] [[40-bit encryption|40-bit]] [[stream cipher]] algorithm. The system was introduced around 1996 and was first compromised in 1999.
CSS is one of several complementary systems designed to [[DVD-Video#Restrictions|restrict DVD-Video]] access.
It has been superseded by newer DRM schemes such as [[Content Protection for Recordable Media]] (CPRM), or by [[Advanced Encryption Standard]] (AES) in the [[Advanced Access Content System]] (AACS) DRM scheme used by [[HD DVD]] and [[Blu-ray Disc]], which have 56-bit and 128-bit [[key size]]s, respectively, providing a much higher [[level of security]] than the less secure 40-bit key size of CSS.
==Preliminary note==
The content scramble system (CSS) is a collection of proprietary protection mechanisms for [[DVD-Video]] discs. CSS attempts to restrict access to the content only for licensed applications. According to the [[DVD Copy Control Association]] (CCA), which is the consortium that grants licenses, CSS is supposed to protect the intellectual property rights of the content owner.
The details of CSS are only given to licensees for a fee. The license,<ref name=css-license>[http://www.dvdcca.org/Documents/CSS_license_ver_1_2.pdf DVD CCA CSS License Agreement] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150530224136/http://www.dvdcca.org/Documents/CSS_license_ver_1_2.pdf |date=2015-05-30 }}</ref> which binds the licensee to a [[non-disclosure agreement]], wouldn't permit the development of [[open-source software]] for DVD-Video playback. Instead, there is [[libdvdcss]], a [[Reverse engineering|reverse engineered]] implementation of CSS. Libdvdcss is a source for documentation, along with the publicly available [[DVD]]-ROM-<ref name=ecma267>[http://www.ecma-international.org/publications/files/ECMA-ST/Ecma-267.pdf Standard ECMA-267, 3rd edition, 2001, 120 mm DVD - Read-Only Disk]</ref> and [[SCSI Multimedia Commands|MMC]]-<ref name=mmc5>[http://www.t10.org/cgi-bin/ac.pl?t=f&f=mmc5r04.pdf Multi-Media Commands - 5 (Working Draft) T10/1675D, Revision 4, 2006-10-24]</ref> specifications. There has also been some effort to collect CSS details from various sources.<ref name=css-study>[https://github.com/helo2804/css_study/raw/release.1/doc/CSS.pdf The Content Scramble System – A Study]</ref>
A DVD-Video can be produced with or without CSS. The publisher may for instance decide to go without CSS protection to save license and production costs.
==Introduction==
The content scramble system deals with three participants: the disc, the drive and the player. The disc holds the copyright information and the encrypted feature. The drive provides the means to read the disc. The player decrypts and presents the audio and visual content of the feature. All participants must conform to the CCA's license agreement.
There are three protection methods: *Playback protection is based on encryption: the player requires a secret key to decrypt the feature. *Read protection is based on the drive: access to significant disc data is only granted if the player authenticates successfully. *Regional restriction is based on the disc and the drive: the drive can deny access if the disc doesn't belong to the drive's region.
The first two protection methods have been broken. Circumvention of regional protection is not possible with every drive -- even if the drive grants access to the feature, prediction of title keys may fail.<ref name=css-study>[https://github.com/helo2804/css_study/raw/release.1/doc/CSS.pdf The Content Scramble System – A Study]</ref> However, drives which do not enforce regional restrictions are inexpensive and widely available, which makes regional restrictions largely ineffective as a component of CSS.
==The disc== The DVD-ROM's main-data (§16<ref name=ecma267 />), which are consecutive logical blocks of 2048 bytes, are structured according to the DVD-Video format. The DVD-Video contains (besides others) an [[MPEG program stream]] which consists of so-called Packs. If CSS is applied to the disc then a subset of all Packs is encrypted with a title-key.
A DVD-ROM contains, besides the main-data, additional data areas. CSS stores there: *a flag that indicates whether CSS is applied or not (§6.23.3.2.2<ref name=mmc5 />), *the 8-bit region-management-information ([[DVD region code|region code]]), *a disc-key-block that holds 409 encrypted variants of the disc-key (§6.23.3.2.3<ref name=mmc5 />).
CSS also uses six bytes in the frame header for each logical block of user data (§16.3,<ref name=ecma267 />§6.29.3.1.5<ref name=mmc5 />): *one byte with copyright management information, *five bytes holding an encrypted title-key.
==The drive== The drive treats a DVD-Video disc as any DVD-ROM disc. The player reads the disc's user-data and processes them according to the DVD-Video format. However, if the drive detects a disc that has been compiled with CSS, it denies access to logical blocks that are marked as copyrighted (§6.15.3<ref name=mmc5 />). The player has to execute an authentication handshake first (§4.10.2.2<ref name=mmc5 />). The authentication handshake is also used to retrieve the disc-key-block and the title-keys.
The drive may also support [[Regional Playback Control]] (RPC) to limit the playback of DVD-Video content to specific regions of the world (§3.3.26<ref name=mmc5 />). RPC Phase II drives hold an 8-bit region-code and adhere to all requirements of the CSS license agreement (§6.29.3.1.7<ref name=mmc5 />). It appears that RPC Phase II drives reject title-key requests on region mismatch. However, reading of user-data may still work.<ref name=css-study />
==The cipher== CSS employs a [[stream cipher]] and mangles the [[keystream]] with the plain-text data to produce the cipher text.<ref name=cryptanalysis /> The stream cipher is based on two [[linear feedback shift register]] (LFSR) and set up with a 40-bit seed.
Mangling depends on the type of operation. There are three types: *the decryption of a disc- or title-key, *the decryption of a Pack and *the encryption of keys for the authentication handshake.
In order to decrypt a DVD-Video, the player reads the disc-key-block and uses its player-key to decrypt the disc-key. Thereafter, the player reads the title-keys and decrypts them with the disc-key. A different title-key can be assigned for the [[DVD-Video#Directory and file structure|Video Manager]] and for each [[DVD-Video#Directory and file structure|Video Title Set]]. The title-keys are used to decrypt the Packs.<ref name=css-study />
==Cryptanalysis== CSS employs cryptographic keys with a size of only 40 bits. This makes CSS vulnerable to a [[brute-force attack]]. At the time CSS was introduced, it was forbidden in the United States for manufacturers to [[Export of cryptography in the United States|export]] cryptographic systems employing keys in excess of 40 bits, a key length that had already been shown to be wholly inadequate in the face of increasing computer processing power (see [[Data Encryption Standard]]).
Based on the leaked [[DeCSS]] source-code, [[Frank A. Stevenson]] published in November 1999 three exploits that rendered the CSS cipher practically ineffective:<ref name=cryptanalysis>{{cite journal | url=http://www.dvd-copy.com/news/cryptanalysis_of_contents_scrambling_system.htm | title=Cryptanalysis of Contents Scrambling System | date=November 8, 1999 | author=[[Frank A. Stevenson]] | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20000302000206/http://www.dvd-copy.com/news/cryptanalysis_of_contents_scrambling_system.htm | archivedate=March 2, 2000 | deadurl=yes | df= }}</ref> *A [[correlation attack]] enables the recovery of a keystream's seed at complexity of 2<sup>16</sup>. *The mangling of disc- and title-keys can be reversed at a complexity of 2<sup>8</sup>. *A disc-key can be recovered from its hash-value at a complexity of 2<sup>25</sup>. The latter exploit recovers a disk-key from its hash-value in less than 18 seconds on an Intel Pentium III @ 450 MHz.
The CSS design was prepared for the leak of a few player-keys. New discs wouldn't contain an encrypted variant for these player-keys in the disc-key-block. However, Stevenson's exploits made it possible to generate all player-keys. [[Libdvdcss]] uses such a list of generated player-keys.
There are cases when no title-keys are available. A drive may deny access on region mismatch but still permit reading of the encrypted DVD-Video. Ethan Hawke presented a plain-text prediction for data repetitions in the [[MPEG program stream]] that enables the recovery of title-keys in real-time directly from the encrypted DVD-Video.<ref name=prediction>[https://cyberside.net.ee/ripping/DeCSSplus_v1.0.zip Ethan Hawke: DeCSSplus (Source Code)]</ref>
In ''[[Geeks Bearing Gifts]]'', author [[Ted Nelson]] states "DVD encryption was intentionally made light by the DVD encryption committee, based on arguments in a libertarian book [[Computer Lib]].", a claim cited as originating from personal communication with an [[anonymous source]]; Nelson is the author of ''Computer Lib''.<ref>{{cite book|last=Nelson|first=Ted|title=Geeks bearing gifts : how the computer world got this way|year=2008|publisher=Mindful Press|location=Sausalito, CA|isbn=978-0-578-00438-9|pages=199|edition=Ed. 1.0.}}</ref>
==See also== * [[DVD Copy Control Association]] * [[libdvdcss]], a popular free software for enabling playback of discs on opensource players.
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * {{official website|http://www.dvdcca.org/css.aspx }} * {{cite web |url= http://www.tinyted.net/eddie/css.html |title= The Content Scrambling System: A Technical Description |series= Synopsis |first= Eddie |last= Edwards |website= Tiny Ted Collective }} * {{cite web |url= http://www.math.ucsd.edu/~crypto/Projects/MarkBarry/ |title= Cryptography in Home Entertainment: A look at content scrambling in DVDs |first= Mark |last= Barry |date= June 2004 |series= Math |website= UCSD }}
[[Category:History of cryptography]] [[Category:Compact Disc and DVD copy protection]] [[Category:Broken stream ciphers]] [[Category:Television technology]] [[Category:Digital rights management standards]] [[Category:DVD Copy Control Association]]
