{{Infobox person | name = Cristina Magno Patwa | image = | birth_name = Cristina Marie Abrina Magno | birth_place = | residence = | occupation = Co-CEO, FactoryMade Ventures | alma_mater = [[Boston University]]
[[UCLA Anderson School of Management]] | boards = [[El Rey Network]]
Tres Pistoleros Studios | website = {{URL|http://factorymade.com}} }}'''Cristina "Cris" Magno Patwa''' is the co-CEO of FactoryMade Ventures, a Los Angeles-based entertainment and media incubator. {{cite web|last1=March|first1=Robert|title=Showbiz Strategists: Variety’s Dealmakers Impact Report|url=https://variety.com/gallery/showbiz-strategists-variety-dealmakers-impact-report/#!3/executives-john-fogelman-and-cristina-patwa/|website=www.variety.com|publisher=Variety|accessdate=15 August 2014|date=December 10, 2013}}{{Cite web|url=http://www2.dca.ca.gov/pls/wllpub/WLLQRYNA$LCEV2.QueryView?P_LICENSE_NUMBER=112111&P_LTE_ID=783|title=California Board of Accountancy - License Lookup|last=California|first=State of|website=www2.dca.ca.gov|language=en|access-date=2018-01-25}} == Early life and education == Patwa, who grew up in the Philippines, attended Boston University. Following her graduation, she attended the Anderson School of Management at UCLA, and was awarded an MBA in 2007. She was licensed as a CPA in California in 2011.{{cite news|title=Mixin' Rhythm: Fusion Blends Different Dance Styles|publisher=Daily Free Press|date=November 7, 2001|quote=The group was created in 1995 to provide BU students with a hip-hop dance, said President and School of Management senior Cristina Magno.}}{{cite web|title=UCLA Anderson TED Week Schedule|url=http://blogs.anderson.ucla.edu/anderson/page/31/|website=blogs.anderson.edu.com|publisher=UCLA Anderson School|accessdate=18 August 2014|date=February 27, 2012}}{{cite web|title=California Board of Accountancy|url=http://www2.dca.ca.gov/pls/wllpub/WLLQRYNA$LCEV2.QueryView?P_LICENSE_NUMBER=112111&P_LTE_ID=783|website=www2.dca.ca.gov|publisher=Department of Consumer Affairs|accessdate=18 August 2014}} == Career == After a brief tenure at Fox Filmed Entertainment, Patwa was hired by Disney ABC Television as a director of business development. She remained at Disney ABC until 2008, when she joined [[William Morris Endeavor]] (WME) as Vice President, Intellectual Property. She was named Senior Vice President and Head of Strategic Planning and Business Development in 2009.{{cite news|last1=Miller|first1=Daniel|title=FactoryMade builds up cast of Hollywood players for El Rey Network|url=http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/envelope/cotown/la-fi-ct-factorymade-20130910-story.html#page=1|accessdate=18 August 2014|publisher=Los Angeles Times|date=September 10, 2013}} At WME, in addition to working with [[Telefonica]] and [[JC Penney]], Patwa served as an advisor to [[Hasbro]] on the ''[[Transformers (film)|Transformers]]'' and ''[[G.I. Joe: The Rise of Cobra|GI Joe]]'' film franchises. She consulted on the creation of [[Hasbro Studios]]' [[Hub Network]] (with [[Discovery Communications]]) and on the development and launch of [[Home Shopping Network|HSN]]'s HSN Arcade. Patwa worked closely with WME founding board member [[John Fogelman]] during her three-year tenure at the company. In 2011, Patwa and Fogelman left WME to found FactoryMade Ventures. At launch, the company announced initial alliances with [[Telefonica]], Hasbro, [[RTL Group]], Michael Bay, [[Robert Rodriguez]], [[Thom Beers]] and Whoopi Goldberg, in addition to J.J. Abrams, who was then a principal investor. Abrams withdrew from the company in January 2012, reportedly due to his schedule.{{cite news|last1=Finke|first1=Nikki|title=J.J. Abrams No Longer Investor In John Fogelman’s Factorymade Ventures: "Not A Good Fit"|url=http://www.deadline.com/2012/01/j-j-abrams-no-longer-investor-in-john-fogelmans-factorymade-ventures-not-a-good-fit/|accessdate=30 June 2014|publisher=Deadline|date=January 21, 2012}}{{cite web|last1=Kilday|first1=Gregg|title=Former WME Agent John Fogelman Launches Development and Consulting Firm|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/wme-agent-john-fogelman-launches-231598|website=variety.com|publisher=The Hollywood Reporter|accessdate=18 August 2014|date=September 6, 2011}}{{cite web|last1=Kenneally|first1=Tim|title=John Fogelman Launches FactoryMade Ventures|url=http://www.thewrap.com/tv/article/john-fogelman-launches-factorymade-ventures-30719/|website=thewrap.com|publisher=The Wrap|accessdate=18 August 2014|date=September 6, 2011}} In November 2014, [[Mitsui & Co.]] purchased a minority stake in FactoryMade.{{cite news|last1=Shaw|first1=Lucas|title=Japanese Conglomerate Mitsui Invests in Hollywood|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2014-11-19/japanese-conglomerate-mitsui-invests-in-hollywood|accessdate=25 April 2015|publisher=Bloomberg|date=November 18, 2014}} In December 2013, FactoryMade partnered with [[Robert Rodriguez]] to create the [[El Rey (TV network)|El Rey]] network, an English language American television channel targeting Latino audiences. In addition to serving on the board of directors for El Rey, Patwa is an executive producer for Rodriguez' original series ''[[From Dusk till Dawn: The Series|From Dusk Til Dawn]]'', and El Rey’s second original scripted series, ''[[Matador (U.S. TV series)|Matador]]''.{{cite web|title=Executive Profiles: Cristina Patwa|url=https://variety.com/exec/cristina-patwa/|website=variety.com|publisher=Variety|accessdate=18 August 2014}} She is on the board of directors for Tres Pistoleros Studios, which she co-founded, and is an executive producer for the studio's ''Director's Chair,'' ''Lucha Underground,'' ''Cutting Crew'' and, with [[Scott Gurney|Scott and Dierdre Gurney]], an untitled ''[[Vice (magazine)|Vice]]'' Mexico series.{{cite web|last1=de Moraes|first1=Lisa|title=TCA: Mark Burnett To Launch Lucha Libre AAA League In U.S. With El Rey Network; ‘From Dusk Till Dawn’ To Premiere In March|url=http://deadline.com/2014/01/tca-mark-burnett-to-launch-lucha-libre-aaa-league-in-u-s-with-el-rey-network-662728/|website=deadline.com|publisher=Deadline|accessdate=18 August 2014}}{{cite web|last1=Brooks|first1=Brian|title=Robert Rodriguez's Comcast Network Targets Next Generation Of U.S. Latinos|url=http://deadline.com/2012/02/robert-rodriguezs-comcast-network-targets-next-generation-of-u-s-latinos-233972/|website=deadline.com|publisher=Deadline|accessdate=February 21, 2012|date=February 21, 2012}} == External links == * [http://www.factorymade.com/home.html FactoryMade ] * [http://www.elreynetwork.com/ El Rey Network ] ==References== {{reflist|2}} {{U.S. broadcast television}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Patwa, Cristina}} [[Category:American women chief executives]] [[Category:American chief executives]] [[Category:American television producers]] [[Category:Women television producers]] [[Category:American entertainment industry businesspeople]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Boston University alumni]] [[Category:UCLA Anderson School of Management alumni]] [[Category:Talent agents]]

{{Refimprove|date=December 2009}} '''Dual role''' (also known as '''double role''', '''triple role''' and '''multiple role''') refers to one actor playing two or more roles, which may be deliberately scripted in a play or film, or merely be a by-product of a low budget. In a theatrical production where more than one actor plays multiple characters, it is sometimes referred to as an "Ironman" cast. In film and television, a dual role is commonly used either for comic effect or to depict [[identical twin]]s.
==Theatre== In [[theatre]], the use of multiple roles may be budget-related, may be intended to give an accomplished actor more stage time or a greater challenge, or may be of thematic significance to the story. The combination of factors leading to such a decision may often remain unknown. For example, debate exists over the significance of [[William Shakespeare]]'s use of dual roles, with a notable example being whether the characters of Cordelia and the Fool in ''[[King Lear]]'' were intended to be one and the same.
More recent examples include:
* In stage productions of ''[[Peter Pan]]'', it is a tradition for Mr. Darling and Captain Hook to be played by the same actor, a tradition often continued in film adaptations with the actors playing dual roles.
* In the works of [[absurdism|absurdists]] such as [[Tom Stoppard]], characters played by the same actor are often of thematic significance.
* In [[Tony Kushner]]'s ''[[Angels in America]]'', a cast of eight actors are each assigned multiple roles for reasons that may include encouraging the audience to consider the elasticity of gender and sexual identities.
* In the musical ''[[Hamilton (musical)|Hamilton]]'', four actors/actresses are cast in dual roles, each a major supporting character, with a change of roles between the first and second acts. The actors who play [[John Laurens]]/[[Philip Hamilton]], [[Gilbert du Motier, Marquis de Lafayette|Lafayette]]/[[Thomas Jefferson]], and [[Hercules Mulligan]]/[[James Madison]] wear identical white costumes in the opening song, "[[Alexander Hamilton (song)|Alexander Hamilton]]", and were given lines with intentional double meanings that would fit either of their dual roles.<ref name=MirandaMcCarter2016/> The actress who plays [[Peggy Schuyler]]/[[Maria Reynolds]] is also double casted.
== Film == {{See also|List of actors who have played multiple roles in the same film}} ===Hollywood=== ''[[The Prisoner of Zenda]]'', based on a book about a lookalike who assumes the identity of a king, includes a dual role that has been played by [[Lewis Stone]] ([[The Prisoner of Zenda (1922 film)|1922 version]]), [[Ronald Colman]] ([[The Prisoner of Zenda (1937 film)|1937 version]]), [[Stewart Granger]] ([[The Prisoner of Zenda (1952 film)|1952 version]]), and [[Peter Sellers]] ([[The Prisoner of Zenda (1979 film)|1979 version]]).
An early and unusual example of double casting was the 1925 silent film ''[[Lady of the Night]]'', in which two women were portrayed by [[Norma Shearer]] to spotlight their very different social classes, and nobody took any notice of their identical appearance.
In ''[[The Wizard of Oz (1939 film)|The Wizard of Oz]]'' (1939), the actors who played the Tin Man, the Cowardly Lion, and the Scarecrow also played farmhands in scenes set in Kansas. [[Margaret Hamilton (actress)|Margaret Hamilton]] played both the roles of Miss Gulch and the Wicked Witch of the West, and [[Frank Morgan]] played multiple characters in addition to the title role of the Wizard.
[[Lee Marvin]] won an [[Academy Award for Best Actor]] for a dual role in ''[[Cat Ballou]]'' (1965), and [[Nicolas Cage]] was nominated for Best Actor for a dual role in ''[[Adaptation (film)|Adaptation]]'' (2002).
In some low-budget films, actors have been cast in more than one role to save money. For example, in one of [[Peter Jackson]]'s early films, ''[[Bad Taste]]'', Jackson played two characters; in one scene, one of them tortures the other.
Multiple casting has been used for comic effect in film, with notable examples that include: * Peter Sellers in movies such as ''[[Dr. Strangelove]]'' (1964) and ''[[The Prisoner of Zenda (1979 film)|The Prisoner of Zenda]]'' (1979) * [[Mike Myers]] in the [[Austin Powers (film series)|''Austin Powers'' film series]] (1997–2002) * [[Buster Keaton]] in his 1921 film ''[[The Playhouse (film)|The Playhouse]]'', playing nearly every part
Particularly in comedies, multiple casting has often included the casting of an actor as multiple members of the same family. For example: * In the [[Back to the Future (franchise)|''Back to the Future'' franchise]], actor [[Michael J. Fox]] played [[Marty McFly]] and McFly's son and daughter, including an appearance as all three characters at the same time in a dinner scene, while [[Thomas F. Wilson]] played [[Biff Tannen]], his grandson [[Griff Tannen]], and his great-grandfather Buford "Mad Dog" Tannen. * [[Alec Guinness]] played all eight members of one family in ''[[Kind Hearts and Coronets]]'' (1949). * [[Eddie Murphy]] played the title character and almost every member of his family in ''[[The Nutty Professor (1996 film)|The Nutty Professor]]'' (1996) and [[Nutty Professor II: The Klumps|its sequel]] (2000).
===India and Bollywood=== Prior to [[Bollywood]], the first double role in Indian cinema was played by [[Ashok Kumar]] in his film [[Kismet (1943 film)|''Kismet'']] in 1943. [[Tamil cinema|Tamil film]] actor [[M. N. Nambiar]] played eleven parts in the early 1950s film ''Digambara Samiyar'', as a sage using nine disguises to defeat an evil lawyer.
Starting in the 1970s, having a living double in a Bollywood film became "almost a genre in itself," according to filmmaker [[Govind Nihalani]].<ref name=Gulzar2003/> The first double role in Bollywood, played by [[Amitabh Bachchan]], was in the film ''[[Bandhe Haath]]'' in 1973. ''[[Angoor (1982 film)|Angoor]]'' (1982) featured two pairs of identical twins, played by [[Sanjeev Kumar]] and [[Deven Verma]]. Another Tamil actor, [[Kamal Hassan]], had ten roles in the 2008 film ''[[Dasavathaaram]] (The Ten Avatars)''. [[Sivaji Ganesan]] played nine roles in the Tamil film ''Navarathiri''. [[Priyanka Chopra]] played the roles of twelve eligible girls in the movie ''[[What's Your Raashee?]]'', and [[Mehmood Ali]] portrayed three generations of the Kapoor family (Prithviraj, Raj, and Randhir) in the movie ''[[Humjoli]]''.
==Television== In [[television]], [[soap opera]]s commonly use the technique to either portray [[twins]] (or even similar looking relatives), or to bring an actor back whose character has been killed. This technique is uncommon, although not unheard of, in [[primetime]] television. In ''[[Friends]]'', Lisa Kudrow plays Phoebe and her twin sister Ursula. David Schwimmer played a character in heavy make-up named Russ, who was a parody of Ross (played by Schwimmer), both of whom appear on screen together.
In the 1967 ''[[Star Trek: The Original Series|Star Trek]]'' episode titled "[[Mirror, Mirror (Star Trek: The Original Series)|Mirror, Mirror]]", as well as its sequels in episodes of three later ''Star Trek'' series (''[[Star Trek: Deep Space Nine]]'', ''[[Star Trek: Enterprise]]'', and ''[[Star Trek: Discovery]]''), several of the regular characters visited or switched places with morally-inverted counterparts from a parallel [[Mirror Universe]], with the actors playing dual roles.
In the third season of ''[[Fargo (TV series)|Fargo]]'', [[Ewan McGregor]] was cast in the lead dual role as the brothers Emmit and Ray Stussy.
''[[The Vampire Diaries]]'' [[The Originals (TV series)|franchise]] features [[Nina Dobrev]] playing four roles (doppelgangers [[Elena Gilbert]], Katerina Petrova, Tatia, and their progenitor Amara) and [[Paul Wesley]] playing three roles (doppelgangers [[Stefan Salvatore]], Tom Avery, and their progenitor Silas).
''[[The Lying Game]]'' and ''[[Liv and Maddie]]'' both feature twins played by the same actress ([[Alexandra Chando]] and [[Dove Cameron]], respectively).
==References== {{Reflist|30em|refs= <ref name=Gulzar2003>{{cite book |editor-last1=Gulazāra |editor-link1=Gulzar |editor-last2=Nihalani |editor-first2=Govind |editor-link2=Govind Nihalani |editor-last3=Chatterjee |editor-first3=Saibal |title=Encyclopaedia of Hindi Cinema |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=8y8vN9A14nkC&pg=PT213 |year=2003 |publisher=Popular Prakashan |isbn=978-81-7991-066-5 |page=213}}</ref> <ref name=MirandaMcCarter2016>{{cite book |last1=Miranda |first1=Lin-Manuel |authorlink1=Lin-Manuel Miranda |last2=McCarter |first2=Jeremy |title=Hamilton: The Revolution |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=f4WfCgAAQBAJ&pg=PA17&q=meanings |year=2016 |publisher=Grand Central Publishing |isbn=978-1-4555-6753-9 |pages=17 n.9}}</ref> }}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Dual Role}} [[Category:Acting]]

#REDIRECT [[Rose Schlossberg]]
[[Category:American web series]] [[Category:2016 web series debuts]] [[Category:YouTube series]] [[Category:Drama web series]] [[Category:Comedy web series]] [[Category:Apocalyptic television series]]

The '''Federal Radio Corporation of Nigeria''' ('''FRCN''') is [[Nigeria]]'s publicly funded radio broadcasting organization. Its subsidiary is the domestic radio network known as Radio Nigeria, with FM stations across the 36 states and Zonal station in the 6 geopolitical zones that broadcast on the SW.
==History== The Federal Radio Corporation of Nigeria was founded in 1933 by the British colonial government. Named the Radio Diffusion Service (RDS), it allowed the public to hear the [[British Broadcasting Corporation]]'s foreign radio service broadcasts in certain public locations over loudspeakers.<ref name="FRCNweb">{{cite web|url=http://www.voiceofnigeria.org/about.htm |title=About the FRCN |publisher=Federal Radio Corporation of Nigeria |access-date=2008-04-10 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080327101126/http://www.voiceofnigeria.org/about.htm |archivedate=2008-03-27 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref>
In April 1950, the RDS became the Nigerian Broadcasting Service and introduced radio stations in [[Lagos]], [[Kaduna]], [[Enugu]], [[Ibadan]], and [[Kano]]. This service was reorganized into the Nigerian Broadcasting Corporation (NBC) on April 1, 1957, by act of parliament. Its mission was to "provide, as a public service, independent and impartial broadcasting services". By 1962 the NBC had expanded its broadcast stations into [[Sokoto]], [[Maiduguri]], [[Ilorin]], [[Zaria]], [[Jos]], and [[Katsina]] in the north; [[Port Harcourt]], [[Calabar]], and [[Onitsha]] in the East; and [[Abeokuta]], [[Warri]], and [[Ijebu-Ode]] in the West. Each of these stations was considered a subsidiary station of a regional station. The subsidiary stations broadcast local interest programs during part of the day, and then relayed programming from their regional station during the rest of the broadcast day. National programs were broadcast from two [[shortwave]] transmitters and one [[medium wave]] transmitter located in [[Sogunle]], near Lagos.<ref name="Yearbook1962">{{cite book |title= Nigeria Year Book 1962 |publisher= [[Daily Times of Nigeria]] |year= 1962|pages= 151–153}}</ref>
In late 1960, the Federal Parliament amended the NBC Ordinance to allow the sale of commercial [[advertisements]]. The first ads ran on October 31, 1961, and were broadcast from Lagos. By 1962 regional and provincial broadcasters began selling ads to local businesses. The goal of allowing radio advertisements was to help provide additional funding to NBC stations beyond that received from the government.<ref name="Yearbook1962"/>
The Federal Parliament approved the creation of the [[Voice of Nigeria]] (VON) external shortwave service in 1961. Broadcasts began on January 1, 1961, from [[Lagos State]]. Its initial operations were limited to two hours a day to West Africa, but by 1963 VON had expanded both its coverage and transmission times with the addition of five additional transmitters.<ref name="VON">{{cite web|url=http://www.voiceofnigeria.org/about.htm |title=About Voice of Nigeria |publisher=Voice of Nigeria |accessdate=2008-04-10 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080327101126/http://www.voiceofnigeria.org/about.htm |archivedate=2008-03-27 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref>
In April 1961, with financial assistance from the [[Ford Foundation]] and technical assistance from the British Broadcasting Corporation, NBC began the National School Broadcasting Service in April 1961. The NBC Schools unit broadcast lessons in various school subjects for primary and secondary schools, as well as special programs for teacher training colleges. The Schools unit was based in [[Ibadan]].<ref name="Yearbook1962"/>
The NBC and the Broadcasting Corporation of Northern Nigeria (BCNN) were merged in 1978 to become the Federal Radio Corporation of Nigeria (FRCN). Mediumwave transmitters previously owned by the NBC were transferred to the individual state governments where the transmitters were located. At the same time, the states transferred shortwave transmitters to the FRCN.<ref name="FRCNweb"/>
In 1996, VON installed three high power transmitters at its [[Ikorodu]] transmitter site, allowing worldwide transmissions for the first time.<ref name="VON"/>
==FRCN Today== FRCN's medium wave service, Radio Nigeria, has 25 stations located throughout the country, and together with Voice of Nigeria, considers itself to have the largest radio network in Africa.<ref name="FRCNweb"/> In 2007, FRCN began introducing FM transmitters in some locations, and plans to begin upgrading and modernizing its shortwave and medium wave transmitters in the coming years<ref name="VON"/>
==External links== *[http://www.radionigeria.gov.ng/ Radio Nigeria Online] *[http://www.voiceofnigeria.org/ Voice of Nigeria]
==References== <references />
[[Category:Radio in Nigeria]] [[Category:Publicly funded broadcasters]] [[Category:Radio stations established in 1933]] [[Category:1933 establishments in Nigeria]] [[Category:State media]]

{{Infobox UK legislation |short_title=Gambling Act 2005The citation of this Act by this [[short title]] is authorised by [http://www.legislation.gov.uk/ukpga/2005/19/section/362 section 362] of this Act. |parliament=Parliament of the United Kingdom |long_title=An Act to make provision about gambling. |statute_book_chapter=2005 c 19 |introduced_by= |territorial_extent= |royal_assent=7 April 2005 |commencement= |repeal_date= |amendments= |related_legislation= |repealing_legislation= |status=Amended |original_text=http://www.legislation.gov.uk/ukpga/2005/19/contents/enacted |legislation_history= |theyworkforyou=Gambling Act 2005 |revised_text=http://www.legislation.gov.uk/ukpga/2005/19/contents |}} The '''Gambling Act 2005''' (2005 c 19) is an [[Act of Parliament|Act]] of the [[Parliament of the United Kingdom]]. It mainly applies to [[England and Wales]], and to [[Scotland]], and is designed to control all forms of [[gambling]]. It transfers authority for licensing gambling from the [[Magistrates' court (England and Wales)|magistrates' court]]s to local authorities (specifically unitary authorities, and the councils of metropolitan borough, non-metropolitan district and London boroughs), or to Scottish [[licensing board]]s. The Act also created the [[Gambling Commission]]. The Act gives its objectives as {{quote|1=
  1. preventing gambling from being a source of crime or disorder, being associated with crime or disorder or being used to support crime,
  2. ensuring that gambling is conducted in a fair and open way, and
  3. protecting children and other vulnerable persons from being harmed or exploited by gambling.
}} Some provisions of the bill faced controversy, particularly in its original form, where it would have allowed eight so-called "[[super casino]]s" to be set up. With the Parliamentary session drawing to a close, a compromise was agreed to reduce this to one.{{cite news | url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk_politics/vote_2005/frontpage/4412949.stm | title=Climbdown saves super casino plan | publisher=[[BBC News website]] | date=2005-04-05 | accessdate=2007-08-09 | quote=}} Despite a lengthy bidding process, with [[Manchester]] being chosen as the single planned location, the development was cancelled soon after [[Gordon Brown]] became [[Prime Minister of the United Kingdom]].{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk_politics/7264143.stm | work=BBC News | title=Super-casino proposal is ditched | date=2008-02-26 | accessdate=2010-05-03}} The Act also specifically regulates [[Online gambling|Internet gambling]] for the first time. The law permits gambling companies to advertise on television and radio.{{cite news |last1=Reuben |first1=Anthony |title=Premier League shirts row: The fickle fashions of sponsorship |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/business-45440347 |accessdate=22 September 2018 |publisher=BBC News |date=22 September 2018}} The act is wide-ranging including regulation of lotteries. The "no purchase necessary" clause on on-product promotions and semi-legal competitions went, replaced with the so-called "New Zealand Model" where purchase may be a requirement, if the purchase is at the "normal selling price". The Act, together with regulations and specifications developed by the Gambling Commission, define and in some cases redefine, categories of gaming machines and where they are allowed to be placed. From 1 December 2014, the Gambling (Licensing & Advertising) Act 2014 contributed several updates to the Act, including a requirement that all off-shore gambling brands apply for a licence from the Gambling Commission and submit to a 15% point of consumption (POC) tax on gross profits.[http://www.rightcasino.com/news/new-uk-gambling-law-explained/ "New UK gambling law explained: what's all the fuss about?" ''Right Casino''. Retrieved 6 October 2014.] ==See also== * [[Gaming Act 1845]] * [[Gaming law]] * [[Gambling in the United Kingdom]] ==Notes== {{reflist|2}} ==External links== *[http://www.legislation.gov.uk/ukpga/2005/19/contents The Gambling Act 2005], as amended from the [[The National Archives (United Kingdom)|National Archives]] *[http://www.legislation.gov.uk/ukpga/2005/19/contents/enacted The Gambling Act 2005], as originally enacted from the National Archives *[http://www.legislation.gov.uk/ukpga/2005/19/notes/contents Explanatory notes] to the Gambling Act 2005 *[http://www.culture.gov.uk/what_we_do/Gambling_racing/gambling_act_2005/ Department of Culture note on the Act] {{UK legislation}} [[Category:United Kingdom Acts of Parliament 2005]] [[Category:Gambling legislation]] [[Category:Gambling in the United Kingdom]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox award | name = Grammy Award for Best Rock Performance by a Duo or Group with Vocal | description = quality [[rock music|rock]] song performances by a duo or group with vocals | image = | imagesize = 100px | alt = A gold gramophone trophy with a plaque set on a table | caption = Gilded gramophone trophy presented to Grammy Award winners | presenter = [[National Academy of Recording Arts and Sciences]] | country = United States | year = 1980 | year2 = 2011 | website = [http://www.grammy.com/ grammy.com] }} The '''[[Grammy Award]] for Best Rock Performance by a Duo or Group with Vocal''' was awarded between 1980 and 2011.
The award was discontinued after the 2011 award season in a major overhaul of Grammy categories. From 2012, all solo or duo/group performances (including instrumental performance) in the rock category were shifted to the newly formed '''[[Best Rock Performance]]''' category.
[[U2]] hold the record for most awards with a total of seven, followed by [[Aerosmith]] with a total of four.

{{other|Hammerhead (disambiguation)}} {{Infobox video game |title = Hammer Heads |image = |developer = Nuclide Games |publisher = [[PopCap Games]] |designer = Luc Van den Borre and Dominique Biesmans |engine = [[PopCap Games Framework]] |released = May 23, 2006 |genre = [[Arcade genre|Arcade]] |modes = [[Single player]] |platforms = [[Microsoft Windows|Windows]], [[Browser game|Browser]] }}
'''''Hammer Heads''''' is an [[Action game|action]] [[arcade game]] similar to [[Whac-A-Mole]]. It is developed by Nuclide Games and distributed by [[PopCap Games]].
==Gameplay== [[Image:HammerHead.jpg|250px|left|thumb|Players' objective is to smash the gnomes.]] The objective of the game is to smash the gnomes coming from the holes in the game area. The player controls a hammer with the mouse, and clicking on the gnomes reduces their hearts, displayed on the bottom of the gnome, depending on the power of the hammer. The default hammer takes away one heart, but more powerful hammers can be bought at the shop. There are various gnomes in the game, with different health and characteristics. Care must be taken to avoid clicking on traps, such as bombs. The player starts with five hearts, which is reduced when a click misses, a gnome escapes, or a trap is activated. They can be recovered by clicking on the hearts dropped by gnomes, or purchasing them from the shop. If you hit the item (such as snake or [[roller skates]]) on the background, 500 points will be awarded. The maximum amount of hearts can be raised by making a purchase at the shop as well. If all of the hearts run out, the game is over.
Starting on level five (six in the Deluxe version), the shop begins popping up from holes. If clicked, the player is taken to a new screen where they can buy several things, such as hammers, hearts, and other powerups. Coins are used to purchase items from the shop. There are various way to obtain coins, such as picking them up when left behind by gnomes, completing a bonus round, or defeating certain gnomes and/or in a certain manner.
==Deluxe version== The deluxe version of ''Hammer Heads'' includes a checkpoint system for the regular classic mode. If the player loses all hearts, he/she may continue from a certain level. A new checkpoint is available every five levels. If the player quits the game, the game suspends progress, and the player can continue exactly where he/she started. Hammer Heads Deluxe also includes a marathon mode, which is similar to classic mode, however, the player is given no checkpoints and the game can last indefinitely. ''Hammer Heads Deluxe'' has a trophy system similar to ''[[Chuzzle|Chuzzle Deluxe]]''. When a certain objective is met, a trophy is received and added to the trophy room, where the player can check the trophies earned, as well as find out how to earn the rest. There is also a boss enemy called "King Globus" at the end with approx. 3500 hit points. Defeating the boss unlocks the "Tough Cookie" option, a higher difficulty setting.
PopCap offers a free online version at their site. It is more limited than the deluxe version, which can be downloaded as a free trial for one hour. After the hour has passed, the player must purchase the game.
==External links== *[http://www.popcap.com/hammerheads ''Hammer Heads'' at PopCap Games] *[http://www.nuclide.com/ Nuclide Games]

{{Infobox wrestling promotion |name = Hoodslam |image = |caption = |acronym = |established = 2010 |folded = |style = |location = [[San Francisco Bay Area]] |founder = Sam Khandaghabadi |owner = |parent = |sister = |formerly = |website = http://www.birdswillfall.com/ }}
[[File:Oakland Hoodslam 1.JPG|thumb|The Stoner Brothers, a popular duo at Hoodslam, wrestling Bat Manuel and El Chupacabra]] '''Hoodslam''' is an underground [[professional wrestling]] event that takes place in [[Oakland, California]]. Created in 2010 by Sam Khandaghabadi as a regular gathering for wrestlers who wanted to perform edgier acts for adults, Hoodslam quickly became a popular event in the [[Bay Area]], attracting over 1,000 attendees at each monthly performance. Hoodslam performances combine the athleticism and tropes of professional wrestling with more bizarre, absurd characters, as well as profanity, sexuality, and public consumption of drugs and alcohol, which are not considered appropriate at mainstream professional wrestling events.
== History ==
[[File:Oakland Hoodslam 2.JPG|thumb|Sam Khandaghabadi, founder of Hoodslam, wrestling as The Dark Sheik]]
Hoodslam was founded by Sam Khandaghabadi, who had been wrestling at other venues under the name The Sheik but was fed up with needing to keep his act appropriate for children. He called together other wrestlers he had met on the West Coast and convinced them to come to the Victory Warehouse in Oakland, the place where he lived and where underground metal shows were regularly performed, promising them that profanity and sexuality would be allowed. 15 wrestlers participated in the first Hoodslam, for which Khandaghabadi did not charge admission.
The gathering continued to be held monthly until May 2011, when the landlord of the Victory Warehouse complained about the noise and partying surrounding the event. However, in June 2011, slam poet [[Jamie DeWolf]] invited Khandaghabadi and the other Hoodslam wrestlers to perform as part of his underground variety art show, [[Tourettes Without Regrets]], at a larger warehouse venue in Oakland, the Oakland Metro Opera House. The popularity of their performance ensured them a regularly monthly spot at the Oakland Metro – on the same night as Oakland's [[First Friday (public event)|First Friday]] art gathering – which continued to attract large crowds. In October 2014, for the first time, the 1,000-person venue sold out before the show began.<ref name=vice-hoodslam>{{cite web|last1=Bien-Kahn|first1=Joseph|title=The Drunken, Bloody Pro Wrestling of Hoodslam Isn't for Kids|url=https://www.vice.com/read/hoodslams-drunk-and-bloody-pro-wrestling-isnt-for-kids-666|website=vice.com|publisher=VICE media|accessdate=30 November 2014}}</ref>
Starting in early 2015, an offshoot of Hoodslam, called "Beachslam", began promoting shows in [[Santa Cruz, California]] and [[Knightsen, California]] featuring many of the same performers and characters as Hoodslam--as well as several new, regional or experimental characters.
== Style and characteristics ==
According to Khandaghabadi, Hoodslam, unlike traditional professional wrestling, is a form of [[performance art]]: because the wrestlers do not need to appeal to a young audience and do not have to pretend that their act is real, they can unleash their creativity in a more sophisticated way, simultaneously demonstrating their athleticism and poking fun at the absurdity of professional wrestling.<ref name=sfgate-raunch>{{cite web|last1=Edwards|first1=Dana|title=A little raunch doesn't throw Hoodslam fans|url=http://www.sfgate.com/performance/article/A-little-raunch-doesn-t-throw-Hoodslam-fans-4911878.php|website=SFGate|accessdate=30 November 2014}}</ref> Hoodslam wrestler A.J. Kirsch states that the tagline of the event, "This Is Real," is a tongue-in-cheek reference to the obvious absurdity of the show, which features wrestlers dressed as popular video game characters [[Ken (Street Fighter)|Ken]] and [[Ryu (Street Fighter)|Ryu]], as well as an "invisible" wrestler, Charlie Chaplin, whom the real wrestlers pretend to battle.<ref name=vice-hoodslam /> Unlike the characters and story lines, however, the physical prowess of the performers is real, and their moves are difficult and dangerous.<ref name=sfgate-raunch />
As the show unfolds, the performers chant, "fuck the fans," which, according to O.J. Patterson, is a "unifying war chant" that functions as "part reminder not to take things too seriously and part demand for hedonistic excess."<ref name=bolditalic-crazy>{{cite web|last1=Patterson|first1=O.J.|title=Oakland's Hoodslam Is Crazy; Go To It|url=http://www.thebolditalic.com/articles/4742-oaklands-hoodslam-is-crazy-go-to-it|website=The Bold Italic|accessdate=30 November 2014}}</ref>
== Notable performers == [[File:Paul-london-brian-kendrick-butternuts.png|thumb|Former [[WWE Raw Tag Team Championship|WWE Tag Team Champions]] [[Paul London and Brian Kendrick]] holding the decapitated corpse of Hoodslam's donkey mascot, Butternuts at a May 2015 event. ]] Many former [[WWE]] and [[Extreme Championship Wrestling|ECW]] wrestlers have made appearances at Hoodslam: since 2013, [[Brian Kendrick]], [[Paul London]], [[Drake Younger]], [[Nick Cvjetkovich|Sinn Bodhi]], [[Shelly Martinez]], [[David Heath (wrestler)|Gangrel]], [[Sonny Onoo]] and [[Mustafa Saed]] have performed on the Hoodslam stage.<ref name="pwtorch2015">{{cite web|title=SHOW RESULTS - 1/2 Hoodslam in Oakland, Calif.: The Brian Kendrick, Golden Gig Title match, more|url=http://pwtorch.com/artman2/publish/Arena_Reports_10/article_82618.shtml|website=Pro Wrestling Torch|accessdate= 11 January 2015}}</ref><ref name="pwtorch2014">{{cite web|title=SHOW RESULTS - 9/5 Hoodslam in Oakland, Calif.: THE Brian Kendrick, Shelly Martinez part of this month's show|url=http://pwtorch.com/artman2/publish/Arena_Reports_10/article_80635.shtml|website=Pro Wrestling Torch|accessdate= 11 January 2015}}</ref><ref name="pwtorch2013">{{cite web|title=SHOW RESULTS - 4/5 Hoodslam in Oakland, Calif.: Three-year Anniv. show features Mustafa, A.J. Kirsch, Bodhi, Lethal Lottery Tag Team Tournament Battlebowl Championship|url=http://www.pwtorch.com/artman2/publish/Arena_Reports_10/article_69872.shtml|website=Pro Wrestling Torch|accessdate= 11 January 2015}}</ref>

{{multiple image | align = right | direction = vertical | width = 220
| image1 = Jack-in-the-box.jpg | alt1 = | caption1 = A generic jack-in-the-box
| image2 = Jack-in-the-box 1863 Harpers.png | alt2 = | caption2 = Two boys playing with a jack-in-the-box in an 1863 illustration }} [[File:Jack in the box after Gavarni.jpg|thumb|Jack-in-the-box after [[Paul Gavarni]].]] A '''jack-in-the-box''' is a [[child]]ren's [[toy]] that outwardly consists of a [[box]] with a [[Crankset|crank]].<ref name="Sobey2008"/> When the crank is turned, a [[music box]] mechanism in the toy plays a [[melody]]. After the crank has been turned a sufficient amount of times (such as at the end of the melody), there is a "[[Surprise (emotion)|surprise]]":<ref name="Hayes2012"/> the lid pops open and a figure, usually a [[clown]] or [[jester]], pops out of the box. Some jack-in-the-boxes open at [[random]] times when cranked, making the [[startle]] even more effective. Many of those that use "[[Pop Goes the Weasel]]" open at the point in the melody when the word "pop" would be sung. In 2005, the jack-in-the-box was inducted into the [[National Toy Hall of Fame]] due to its frequent charm that captivates children's interest.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.toyhalloffame.org/toys/jack-box|title=Jack-in-the-Box {{!}} National Toy Hall of Fame|website=www.toyhalloffame.org|language=en|access-date=2018-10-22}}</ref> There you will find all types of versions of the toy, stating from the beginning versions, and ending with the most recently manufactured versions.
==Origin== A theory as to the origin of the jack-in-the-box is that it comes from the 14th-century [[England|English]] [[prelate]] [[John Schorne|Sir John Schorne]],<ref name="Vince2008"/> who is often pictured holding a [[boot]] with a [[devil]] in it. According to [[folklore]], he once cast the devil into a boot to protect the village of [[North Marston]] in [[Buckinghamshire]]. In French, a jack-in-the-box is called a "''diable en boîte''" (literally "devil in a box").
== Models == Originally, the jack-in-the-box was a made out of [[wood]] however, as new technology began to come out the toy transformed into printed cardboard<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.toyhalloffame.org/toys/jack-box|title=Jack-in-the-Box {{!}} National Toy Hall of Fame|website=www.toyhalloffame.org|language=en|access-date=2018-10-22}}</ref>, then around the 30s, the jack-in-the-box became a [[Wind-up toy|wind up]] toy made from [[tin]]. Over the years, the jack-in-the-box has evolved into characters other than the clown, such as [[Winnie-the-Pooh|Winnie the Pooh]], the [[The Cat in the Hat|Cat in the Hat]], the [[The Three Little Pigs|Three Little Pigs]], [[Kitten|kittens]], [[Dog|dogs]], [[Curious George]], [[Santa Claus (disambiguation)|Santa Clause]], [[Giraffe|giraffes]], and so on.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.j2e.com/victoria+junior+school/Admin/history+of+pop+up+toys+and+jack+in+the+boxes/|title=history of pop up toys and jack in the boxes|website=www.j2e.com|access-date=2018-10-22}}</ref>
== Distributers == Starting in 1935 and continuing for 20 years, the first company to take on the distribution of the toy, was a very small company named the Joy Toy. This company is located in [[Italy]]<nowiki/> as well as the [[Netherlands]]. Since then, [[Fisher-Price|Fischer Price]], [[Chad Valley (toy brand)|Chad Valley]], as well as [[Tomy]], have all taken major parts in distributing the jack-in-the-box.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.j2e.com/victoria+junior+school/Admin/history+of+pop+up+toys+and+jack+in+the+boxes/|title=history of pop up toys and jack in the boxes|website=www.j2e.com|access-date=2018-10-26}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist|refs= <ref name="Sobey2008">{{Citation | first1 = Ed | last1 = Sobey | first2 = Woody | last2 = Sobey | title = The Way Toys Work: The Science Behind the Magic 8 Ball, Etch a Sketch, Boomerang, and More | publisher = Chicago Review Press | page = 71 | year = 2008
| isbn = 1613743092 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=F2ApK7QnbPUC&pg=PA71 | postscript= . }}</ref>
<ref name="Hayes2012">{{Citation | first1 = Justin Cord | last1 = Hayes | title = The Unexpected Evolution of Language: Discover the Surprising Etymology of Everyday Words | publisher = Adams Media | page = 106 | year = 2012 | isbn = 1440542791 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=1V__EEFEwbcC&pg=PT106 | postscript= . }}</ref>
<ref name="Vince2008">{{Citation | first1 = John | last1 = Vince | title = Discovering Saints in Britain | edition = 3rd | publisher = Osprey Publishing | page = 29 | year = 2008 | isbn = 0747804753 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=pij89MWD_lYC&pg=PA29 | postscript= . }}</ref> }}
==External links== {{commons category inline|Jack-in-the-box}}

page.title: Kristin Chenoweth: My Love Letter to Broadway

revision.comment: standard quote handling in WP;standard Apostrophe/quotation marks in WP; MOS general fixes
revision.text:
{{Infobox musical |name=Kristin Chenoweth: My Love Letter to Broadway |image=KristinOnBroadway.jpg |caption= |music= |lyrics= |book= |basis= |productions=2016 [[Broadway theatre|Broadway]] |awards= }} '''''Kristin Chenoweth: My Love Letter to Broadway''''' is a 2016 musical [[revue]] / concert, written for and starring American singer and actress [[Kristin Chenoweth]]. The show was directed by [[Richard Jay-Alexander]], with musical direction by Mary Mitchell Campbell, and produced by [[James L. Nederlander]]. The show was a limited engagement of 12 performances at [[Broadway theatre|Broadway]]'s [[Lunt-Fontanne Theatre]] from November 2 through 13, 2016.[http://www.kristinonbroadway.com Official website], accessed November 3, 2016Vine, Hannah. [http://www.playbill.com/article/see-kristin-chenoweth-give-final-bow-plus-exclusive-backstage-photos "Exclusive Photos: Go Backstage for Kristin Chenoweth’s Broadway Closing Night"], ''Playbill'', November 14, 2016 ==Production== Chenoweth describes the concert as, "an intimate evening of romance, glamour and laughter."BWW News Desk. [http://www.broadwayworld.com/article/Breaking-News-Kristin-Chenoweth-Will-Return-to-Broadway-This-Fall-with-MY-LOVE-LETTER-TO-BROADWAY-20160906# "Breaking News: Kristin Chenoweth Will Return to Broadway This Fall with ''My Love Letter to Broadway''], BroadwayWorld, September 6, 2016 The production is a limited engagement from November 2 to November 13, 2016. It features a selection of songs performed by Chenoweth during her career, songs from her latest [[Great American Songbook]]-themed album ''[[The Art of Elegance]]'', favorite Broadway standards, and others. "Chenoweth claims that no two shows in this 12-performance engagement will be alike", with the show featuring guest appearances by different youth choirs and other special guests.Rooney, David. [http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/review/kristin-chenoweth-my-love-letter-broadway-944299 "''Kristin Chenoweth: My Love Letter to Broadway'': Theater Review"], ''Hollywood Reporter'', November 4, 2016 The show is directed by [[Richard Jay-Alexander]], who has directed some of Chenoweth's concerts and tours since 2012. Chenoweth's friend Mary Mitchell Campbell serves as musical director, and costumes are designed by [[Christian Siriano]].Haun, Harry. [http://www.playbill.com/article/what-kristin-chenoweth-will-do-for-love "What Kristin Chenoweth Will Do for ''Love''"], ''[[Playbill]]'', October 24, 2016 ==Guest performers and choirs== Chenoweth invites a different surprise guest and/or local choir mainly from the New York City area to perform some songs with her each performance. * November 2 – Youth Pride Chorus[http://www.nycgmc.org/latest-news/2016/11/3/youth-pride-chorus-performs-with-kristin-chenoweth "Youth Pride Chorus Performs on Broadway with Kristin Chenoweth"], New York City Gay Men's Chorus, November 3, 2016 * November 3 – [[Renée Fleming]] and the Alumni of The Performing Arts Project choir * November 4 – [[Alan Cumming]] and the [[Pace University]] ChoirStewart, Zachary. [http://www.theatermania.com/broadway/reviews/kristin-chenoweth-my-love-letter-to-broadway_79047.html ''Kristin Chenoweth: My Love Letter to Broadway''], TheaterMania.com, November 7, 2016 * November 5 – The New Paradigm Theatre College Program[http://www.nptheatre.org/nptevents/npt-interns-to-sing-with-kristin-chenoweth "NPT Interns to Sing With Kristin Chenoweth!"], nptheatre.org, November 2016, accessed November 5, 2016 and [[Norm Lewis]] (evening performance only)Quinn, Dave. [http://www.nbcnewyork.com/entertainment/the-scene/Kristin-Chenoweths-Irresistible-Love-Letter-to-Broadway-400755861.html "Kristin Chenoweth's Irresistible 'Love Letter to Broadway'"], nbcnewyork.com, November 10, 2016, accessed November 11, 2016Chenoweth, Kristin. [https://twitter.com/KChenoweth/status/795063853226725376 "''My Love Letter To Broadway'': Special Guest Norm Lewis"], Twitter.com, November 5, 2016 accessed November 11, 2016 * November 6 – [[Lea DeLaria]][http://www.broadwayworld.com/article/Lea-DeLaria-Will-Appear-on-Broadway-with-Kristin-Chenoweth-This-Weekend-20161104 "Lea DeLaria Will Appear on Broadway with Kristin Chenoweth This Weekend"], ''Broadway World'', November 4, 2016 and [[Mayo Performing Arts Center]] youth chorus, Morristown, New JerseyCouglin, Kevin. [http://morristowngreen.com/2016/11/05/broadway-bound-morristowns-mpac-youth-chorus-to-back-kristin-chenoweth-nov-6/ "Broadway bound: Morristown’s MPAC youth chorus to back Kristin Chenoweth, Nov. 6"], morristowngreen.com, November 5, 2016; and Westhoven, William. [http://www.dailyrecord.com/story/news/2016/11/13/mpac-students-dazzle-2-broadway-audiences/93638666 "MPAC students dazzle 2 Broadway audiences"], ''[[Daily Record (Morristown)|Daily Record]]'', November 13, 2016 * November 9 – [[Jason Robert Brown]]Gioia, Michael. [http://www.playbill.com/article/must-listen-jason-robert-brown-records-song-in-response-to-presidential-election# "Must Listen: Jason Robert Brown Records Song in Response to Presidential Election"], Playbill, November 9, 2016 * November 10 – [[Sierra Boggess]]Chenoweth, Kristin [https://www.facebook.com/kristinchenoweth/videos/10153898953866360 "Sierra Boggess ... [is] joining me tonight!"], Facebook, November 10, 2016; and [http://newyorkbroadwaytours.com/breaking-news-the-special-guest-for-tony-and-emmy-winner-kristin-chenoweths-my-love "Breaking News: The special guest for Tony and Emmy winner Kristin Chenoweth's ''My Love''"], NewYorkBroadwayTours.com, November 10, 2016 and singers from the Manhattan School of Music{{citation needed|date=November 2016}} * November 11 – [[Andrew Lippa]]Chenoweth, Kristin. [https://twitter.com/KChenoweth/status/797266135913730049?lang=en "@lippaofficial is here tonight!"], Twitter.com, November 11, 2016 and the [[Hunter College]] Opera Theatre EnsembleRaab, Jennifer J. [https://twitter.com/HunterPresident/status/797547143565287424 "Hunter College Opera Theater Ensemble students performed last night with @KChenoweth"], Twitter.com, November 12, 2016 * November 12 – [[Kelli O'Hara]] (evening performance only)Chenoweth, Kristin. [https://www.facebook.com/kristinchenoweth/videos/10153904091021360 " Kelli O'Hara!"], Facebook.com, November 12, 2016; and O'Hara, Kelli. [https://www.facebook.com/179306848771730/photos/a.196103110425437.39890.179306848771730/1152261998142872/?type=3&theater "thank you for tonight and for having me on stage with you"], Facebook.com, November 13, 2016 and the [[Furman University]] SingersWard, Carol Anne. [https://news.furman.edu/2016/11/14/one-night-on-broadway "One night on Broadway"], ''Furman News'', November 14, 2016; and Chenoweth, Kristin. [https://twitter.com/KChenoweth "The @FurmanSingers are making their Broadway debut Nov. 12"], Twitter.com, November 11, 2016 * November 13 – [[Andy Karl]]Hetrick, Adam. [http://www.playbill.com/article/broadway-box-office-analysis-november-7-13 "Broadway Box-Office Analysis: November 7–13"], ''Playbill'', November 14, 2016; and Collins, Stephen. [http://livetheatreuk.co.uk/2016/11/13/review-kristin-chenoweth-my-love-letter-to-broadway "Review – Kristin Chenoweth: My Love Letter to Broadway"], LiveTheatreUK.co.uk, November 13, 2016 and the [[Oklahoma City University]] choirGreco, Jonathan. [http://www.koco.com/article/ocu-students-to-join-kristin-chenoweth-on-broadway/8280653 "OCU students to Join Kristin Chenoweth on Broadway"], KOCO5 News, November 11, 2016 ==Songs== The following is a sample of the songs that were performed; Chenoweth stated that "no two shows will be alike." Sources:''The New York Times''; ''Hollywood Reporter''; TheatreMania * "[[You Made Me Love You (I Didn't Want to Do It)|You Made Me Love You]]" * "Let Me Entertain You" from ''Gypsy'' * "[[I Could Have Danced All Night]]" from ''My Fair Lady'' * "Easy Street" from ''Annie'' (duet with Alan Cumming) * "[[Over the Rainbow]]" (duet with Renee Fleming) * "Oklahoma" from ''Oklahoma'' (duet with Kelli O'Hara) * "[[Part of Your World]]" from ''The Little Mermaid'' (duet with Sierra Boggess) * "[[Popular (Wicked song)|Popular]]" from ''Wicked'' * "[[Always on My Mind]]" * "[[Losing My Mind]]" from ''Follies'' * "[[Zing! Went the Strings of My Heart]]" * "[[A House Is Not a Home (song)|A House Is Not a Home]]" interpolated into the 2010 revival of ''Promises, Promises'' * "Fifty Years", by Jason Robert Brown * "Upon This Rock" (with Performing Arts Project choir) * "Bring Him Home" from ''Les Misérables'' * "One" from ''A Chorus Line''Collins, Stephen. [http://livetheatreuk.co.uk/2016/11/13/review-kristin-chenoweth-my-love-letter-to-broadway "Review – Kristin Chenoweth: My Love Letter to Broadway"], LiveTheatreUK.co.uk, November 13, 2016 * "Dance: Ten; Looks: Three" from ''A Chorus Line'' * "I'm Not a Diva" * "[[Moon River]]" * "Little Sparrow" from Dolly Parton's album of the same name * "A Quiet Thing" (Kander and Ebb) * "[[All the Things You Are]]" by Jerome Kern and Oscar Hammerstein * "I Get Along Without You Very Well" * "I'm Tired" from ''Blazing Saddles'' * "I Was Here" (with Performing Arts Project choir) * "I Couldn't Be Happier"Feldman, Adam. [https://www.timeout.com/newyork/blog/broadway-review-kristin-chenoweth-brings-blazing-star-power-to-a-full-length-concert-110816 "Broadway review: Kristin Chenoweth brings blazing star power to a full-length concert"], ''TimeOut'', November 8, 2016 * "[[Smile (Charlie Chaplin song)|Smile]]" ==Reception== [[Charles Isherwood]] of ''[[The New York Times]]'' reviewed the show, writing:
Chenoweth's appeal is in her perky wholesomeness and golly-gee enthusiasm ... which never feel manufactured. She has lost none of the girlish glow she possessed when she first rose to Broadway stardom. ... Nor does her singing ever feel mannered, although her bright lyric soprano is a superbly trained instrument. ... [H]er voice bloomed and soared almost effortlessly, in a wide range of repertoire, much but not all drawn from Broadway shows. ... [I]n a duet with a surprise guest, the opera star [[Renée Fleming]], on "[[Over the Rainbow]]"... Fleming cast an amused eye at Ms. Chenoweth's ... magenta sequined leotard ... and admired her courage for wearing "hot pants."... Chenoweth also brought a reflective quality to [several songs]. ... The band, though numbering just five, sounded plenty plush. ... Chenoweth's lively, natural humor was on ample display. ... Whether singing or delivering her often self-deprecating patter, Ms. Chenoweth always radiates a pleasure in performing that carries across the proverbial footlights ... she's like a singing ray of sunshine.[[Charles Isherwood|Isherwood, Charles]]. [https://www.nytimes.com/2016/11/05/theater/review-kristin-chenoweth-my-love-letter-to-broadway.html?_r=0 "Review: Kristin Chenoweth, That Perky Performer With the Powerhouse Pipes"], ''[[The New York Times]]'', November 4, 2016
==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==External links== *[https://www.ibdb.com/broadway-production/my-love-letter-to-broadway-510068 Internet Broadway Database] {{Kristin Chenoweth}} [[Category:Concerts in the United States]] [[Category:Revues]] [[Category:2016 in New York City]] [[Category:2016 in American music]]

{{Coord|43.8|10.5|display=title}}
{{Infobox Convention | name = Lucca Comics and Games | image = [[File:Lucca Comics 2007 San Michele.JPG|220px]] | caption = A Lucca Comics pavilion, near the [[San Michele in Foro]] basilica, in 2007. | status = active | genre = | venue = | location = [[Lucca]] | country = [[Italy]] | first = [[1965 in comics|1965]] | last = | organizer = [[Comune]] of Lucca, through the limited company "Lucca Comics & Games Srl"<ref>[http://www.luccacomicsandgames.com/it/2013/chi-siamo/ Lucca Comics & Games Srl - Chi siamo]</ref> | filing = | attendance = 272,000 by 2016<ref>{{cite news|publisher=''La Nazione''|url=http://www.lanazione.it/lucca/cronaca/comics-dati-biglietti-2016-1.2644572|title=Comics: 271.208 biglietti venduti. E' il record di sempre|date=1 November 2016}}</ref> | website = [http://www.luccacomicsandgames.com/ luccacomicsandgames.com] }} '''Lucca Comics & Games''' is an annual [[Comic book convention|comic book]] and [[gaming convention]] in [[Lucca]], [[Tuscany]], traditionally held at the end of October. It is the largest [[comics]] festival in [[Europe]], and the second biggest in the world after the [[Comiket]].
== History == [[File:Lucca Comics 2012 - 01.jpg|thumb|Crowd in Vittorio Veneto street during the Lucca Comics and Games 2012]] [[File:Lucca Comics 2007 padiglione.jpg|thumb|Entern of a pavilion]] The '''Salone Internazionale del Comics''' ("International Congress of Comics") was launched by a Franco-Italian partnership, consisting of Italians Rinaldo Traini and Romano Calisi and Frenchman {{ill|Claude Moliterni|fr}} (forming the International Congress of Cartoonists and Animators) in 1965 in [[Bordighera]].<ref>"Lucca 9," ''Bang!'' #11 (1974), p. 55.</ref><ref>Pasamonik, Didier. [http://www.actuabd.com/Disparition-de-Claude-Moliterni-fondateur-du-Festival-d-Angouleme "Disparition de Claude Moliterni, fondateur du Festival d’Angoulême ,"]''ActuaBD'' (Jan. 21, 2009). {{fr icon}}</ref> In 1966 it moved to a small [[piazza]] in the center of Lucca, and grew in size and importance over the years.
Funding issues reduced the frequency of the festival to every two years, beginning in 1977. In the 1980s, the festival was moved to a sports center outside the city walls, where it remained until 1992, when it was moved to another city. (Funding issues also forced the cancellation of the 1988 festival.)
After the Salone internazionale del Comics ended in Lucca, city leaders launched a new convention called simply '''Lucca Comics''' that was a reprise of the old one. In 1996 it changed its name to Lucca Comics & Games. The festival attracted 50,000 attendees in 2002.
Meanwhile, the Salone internazionale del Comics was held in Rome from 1995 to 2005. In 2006, for the festival's 40th anniversary, the Salone merged with Lucca Comics & Games and moved back to Lucca's city center, with numerous tents and pavilions arranged in different squares within and outside the walls of the medieval city.
In 2016, the festival attracted 270,000 attendees.
== Awards == [[File:Lucca Comics 2012 - 03.jpg|thumb|The stage of [[cosplay]].]] [[File:Herbert Ballerina and Maccio Capatonda - Lucca Comics & Games 2016.jpg|thumb|The italian actors [[Herbert Ballerina]] and [[Maccio Capatonda]] at Lucca Comics & Games 2016]] === Comics awards === From 1970–2005, the festival presented the {{Interlanguage link multi|Yellow Kid Award|de|3=Yellow Kid (Preis)|lt=Yellow Kid Award}} — named in honor of [[Richard F. Outcault]]'s seminal comic strip character [[The Yellow Kid]] — in such categories as Best Cartoonist, Best Illustrator, Best Newcomer, Best Foreign Artist, and Lifetime Achievement. Yellow Kid Awards were also presented to publishers, both domestic and foreign. <!-- The festival gives out annual [[Yambo]] Awards, named after [[Enrico Novelli]], an Italian cartoonist who used the pen name "Yambo." [[Don Rico]] was given a Yambo Award. -->
The festival also (since 1967) presents a special award called the {{Interlanguage link multi|Gran Guinigi|it|3=Gran Guinigi|lt=Gran Guinigi Award}} (named after Lucca's [[Guinigi Tower]]).
==== Yellow Kid Award recipients ==== * 1970: [[Johnny Hart]], for Best Cartoonist of the Year — first time this award was given to an American cartoonist<ref>Nordling, Lee. ''Your Career in the Comics'' (Newspaper Features Council (U.S.)/Andrews McMeel Publishing, 1995), p. 235.</ref> * 1972: ** [[Hergé]], for "una vita per il cartooning" (lifetime award)<ref>[http://www.immaginecentrostudi.org/saloni/salone08.asp "History of the Lucca festival"]. 1972. Retrieved 15 July 2006.</ref> ** ''[[Tintin (magazine)|Tintin]]'' magazine, for Best Publication * 1973: [[Guido Buzzelli]], for Best Illustrator and Author * 1974: [[Vaughn Bodé]] * 1975: ** [[Jean Giraud]], for Best Foreign Artist<ref name="salon11">{{cite web|publisher =immaginecentrostudi.org | title = 11° Salone Internationale del Comics, del Film di Animazione e dell'Illustrazione | url =http://www.immaginecentrostudi.org/saloni/salone11.asp |language=it}}</ref> ** [[Dan O'Neill]] ** [[Frank Hampson]], declared ''Prestigioso Maestro'' and the best writer and artist of strip cartoons since the end of the [[Second World War]]{{citation needed|date=June 2015}} * 1977: [[Fred (cartoonist)|Fred]] * 1978: ** [[Bobby London]], Best Artist-Writer ** [[Milo Manara]]<ref>Clute, John and John Grant. ''The Encyclopedia of Fantasy'' (Macmillan, 1999), p. 621</ref> ** [[Carlos Trillo]], for Best International Author<ref name=YK1978>{{Cite web |url=http://www.immaginecentrostudi.org/saloni/salone13.asp |title=13 Salone Internazionale dei Comics |publisher=Centro Studi Iconografici |language=Italian }}</ref> *1980: ** [[Didier Comès]], for Best Foreign Artist ** [[Jean Giraud]], for Best Foreign Author ** [[Frank Margerin]] * 1982: [[Art Spiegelman]], for Best Foreign Author<ref>{{cite web |last=Traini |first=Rinaldo |title=15° SALONE, 1982 |publisher=Immagine-Centro Studi Iconografici |year=1982 |url=http://www.immaginecentrostudi.org/saloni/salone15.asp |language=Italian |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5wQIgLe0i?url=http://www.immaginecentrostudi.org/saloni/salone15.asp |archivedate=2011-02-11 |deadurl=no |ref=harv |df= }}</ref> * 1983: ** [[Gilbert Hernandez]]<ref>[http://www.bailsprojects.com/bio.aspx?Name=HERNANDEZ%2C+GILBERT Gilbert Hernandez entry], ''Who's Who of American Comic Books, 1928-1999''. Accessed June 15, 2015.</ref> ** [[Jaime Hernandez]]<ref>"Hernandez Brothers Win Award," ''The Comics Journal'' #95 (Feb. 1985), p. 21.</ref> * 1984: [[Strip Art Features]], for Best Foreign Comics Publisher<ref name="YK Awards-1984">{{cite web| last =Immagine-Centro Studi Iconografici | title =16° SALONE INTERNAZIONALE DEI COMICS, 1984 | url = http://www.immaginecentrostudi.org/saloni/salone16.asp | language=Italian }}</ref> * 1986: [[Bill Sienkiewicz]], for "bridging the gap between American and European artistic sensibilities"<ref name="W&P-BS">{{cite web |url= http://www.wordsandpictures.org/Elektra/elektra19.html|title= Bill Sienkiewicz Awards, Exhibits|publisher= Wordsandpictures.org|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20120207173843/http://www.wordsandpictures.org/Elektra/elektra19.html|archivedate= February 7, 2012|deadurl= no}}</ref><ref name="YellowKid-86">{{cite web|publisher= Immagine-Centro Studi Iconografici|title =17° SALONE, 1986|url =http://www.immaginecentrostudi.org/saloni/salone17.asp|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20120207041827/http://www.immaginecentrostudi.org/saloni/salone17.asp|archivedate= February 7, 2012|deadurl= no|language=it}}</ref> * 1990: ** [[Neil Gaiman]]<ref>[http://www.neilgaiman.com/About_Neil/Awards_and_Honors "Awards and Honors,"] NeilGaiman.com. Accessed June 16, 2015.</ref> ** [[Massimo Rotundo]], for Best Italian Comics Artist ** [[Leonardo Ortolani]], for Best Newcomer * 1993: ** [[John Byrne (comics)|John Byrne]]<ref name=Lucca93>Origa, Graziano. "Lucca Exhibition is Un Grande Successo: Yellow Kid Awards for John Byrne, François Boucq, Frank Thomas, and Ollie Johnston," ''The Comics Journal'' #156 (Feb. 1993), p. 41.</ref> ** [[François Boucq]]<ref name=Lucca93 /> ** [[Frank Thomas (animator)|Frank Thomas]]<ref name=Lucca93 /> ** [[Ollie Johnston]]<ref name=Lucca93 /> * 1998: [[Paul Gillon]] * 1999: [[Jeff Smith (cartoonist)|Jeff Smith]], Best Author<ref>Duncan, Randy, and Matthew J. Smith. ''Icons of the American Comic Book: From Captain America to Wonder Woman'', vol. 1, (ABC-CLIO, 2013), p. 98</ref>
==== Gran Guinigi recipients ==== * 1969: [[Hugo Pratt]], for ''Una ballata del mare salato''<ref>{{Cite web|last=Centro Studi Iconografici|url=http://www.immaginecentrostudi.org/saloni/salone05.asp |title=5 Salone Internazionale dei Comics|language=Italian}}</ref> * 1975: [[Dan O'Neill]] for ''The Penny-Ante Republican''<ref>[http://www.bailsprojects.com/bio.aspx?Name=O%27NEILL%2c+DAN O'Neill entry], ''Who's Who of American Comic Books, 1928-1999''. Accessed Oct. 8, 2016.</ref> * 1978: [[Carlos Trillo]]<ref name=YK1978 /> * 1986: [[Bill Sienkiewicz]]<ref name="W&P-BS" /><ref name="YellowKid-86"/> * 1990: [[Massimo Rotundo]] * 2011: [[Boichi]], for ''Hotel''
=== Games awards === * 2002: [[Emiliano Sciarra]]'s [[Wild West]]-themed card game ''[[Bang! (card game)|Bang!]]'', for Best of Show * 2003: ''[[Sine Requie]]'', for Best Italian Game * 2004: [[Helena Bulaja]]'s ''Priče iz davnine'' ("''Croatian Tales of Long Ago''"), for Best Multimedia Award * 2010: ** ''[[7 Wonders (board game)|7 Wonders]]'', for Best Card Game ** ''[[Eden: the Deceit]]'', Side Award for Best Game Mechanics * 2011: [[Vincent Baker]]'s ''[[Apocalypse World]]'', for RPG of the Year
== References == {{reflist|2}}

{{Infobox company | logo = Magmic logo.png | logo_size = 180px | name = Magmic Inc. | type = [[Privately held company|Private]] | foundation = 2002 | founder = | location = [[Ottawa]], [[Ontario]], Canada | key_people = John Criswick, <small>CEO</small> | revenue = | industry = [[Video game industry|Video games]] | products = | num_employees = 51-200 (2011)<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.linkedin.com/company/346326?goback=%2Efcs_GLHD_magmic_false_*2_*2_*2_*2_*2_*2_*2_*2_*2_*2_*2_*2&trk=ncsrch_hits | title = Number of employees | publisher = LinkedIn | date = 2011-12-01 | accessdate = 2011-12-01}}</ref> | divisions = | owner = | homepage = [http://www.magmic.com/ www.magmic.com] }} '''''Magmic Inc.''''' is an [[Ottawa]]-based developer and publisher of mobile entertainment and lifestyle software.<ref>[http://www.businessweek.com/technology/content/mar2007/tc20070322_018503.htm?campaign_id=rss_tech Gaming Goes Business Casual] via [[BusinessWeek]]</ref><ref>[http://www.canada.com/ottawacitizen/story.html?id=de9ff3c2-bc5d-44b0-9054-330eb7007db5 Ottawa's major players] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090906132902/http://www.canada.com/ottawacitizen/story.html?id=de9ff3c2-bc5d-44b0-9054-330eb7007db5 |date=2009-09-06 }} via [[The Ottawa Citizen]]</ref> Founded in 2002, Magmic produces content based on both original and licensed [[intellectual property]]<ref>[http://www.mobilemarketer.com/cms/news/gaming/238.html Magmic Games, IG Fun target smartphone market]</ref> for a variety of handset models, including [[Java ME]], [[Qualcomm Brew|BREW]], Sidekick, [[Windows Mobile]], Apple [[iPhone]], [[Android (operating system)|Android]], and [[BlackBerry]] smartphone devices.
==Distribution== Magmic has distribution deals with carriers worldwide, allowing subscribers to purchase and download Magmic games and other software directly through their handsets.<ref>[http://www.ottawabusinessjournal.com/322897348115793.php 'We're going for top 10 in the world'] via [[Ottawa Business Journal]]</ref> In addition, Magmic has launched several direct-to-consumer portals including Bplay (for the BlackBerry market) and Winplay (for the Windows Mobile market) which allow for a variety of payment and download options. Magmic also sells games for iPhone and iPod Touch through Apple iTunes and has several offerings on [[App World]], the BlackBerry application store launched by [[Research In Motion]] in 2009.
==Connected Games== Magmic developed its own mobile connected gaming platform which allows users to post scores, download daily puzzles, and play head-to-head. Early Magmic titles such as Blackjack Highroller (released in 2002) allowed the player to submit their scores to a centralized server and view high score leaderboards in real time. This technology was expanded to include the downloading of content to the device with games such as Sudoku (2004) and [[Ka-Glom!]] (2005).
True head-to-head mobile connected gaming was realized with the launch of [[Medieval Kings Chess II]] (2004) and Texas Hold'em King 2 (2004), which featured a mixture of live players and AI "bots" playing Texas Hold'em for play money at a virtual table.<ref>[http://www.gamesondeck.com/feature/1538/interview_john_criswick_and_.php Interview: John Criswick and Nicholas Reichenbach, Magmic Games] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080719165201/http://www.gamesondeck.com/feature/1538/interview_john_criswick_and_.php |date=July 19, 2008 }}</ref> THK2 proved very popular and was eventually included as a pre-loaded game on several BlackBerry handsets. THK2 was improved in 2008 with the release of Texas Hold'em King 3, which improved gameplay and added more multiplayer features.
== External links == * [http://www.magmic.com Magmic Website]
== References == {{reflist}}
[[Category:Mobile game companies]] [[Category:Video game companies of Canada]]

revision.text:
{{Orphan|date=March 2018}}
The '''Media Diversity Institute''' ('''MDI''') is a London based non-governmental organisation<ref name=":2">{{cite web|title=Media Diversity Institute|url=http://www.annalindhfoundation.org/members/media-diversity-institute|website=Anna Lindh Foundation}}</ref> working with the media to improve reporting on ethnicity, religion, gender, sexuality and other diversity issues.<ref>{{cite web|title=Media Diversity Institute|url=http://ethicaljournalismnetwork.org/supporters/media-diversity-institute|website=Ethical Journalism Network}}</ref>
The mission of MDI is to promote "responsible journalism as a means to improve inter-community relations, increase tolerance and encourage dialogue among individuals and groups coming from different backgrounds."<ref name=":3">{{cite web|title=Media Diversity Institute|url=https://gfmd.info/en/site/members/886/Media-Diversity-Institute.htm|website=Global Forum for Media Development}}</ref>
MDI has worked with organizations such as [[Internews]],<ref name=":0">{{cite book|url=http://ec.europa.eu/social/main.jsp?langId=en&catId=89&newsId=512|title=Media4Diversity: Taking the Pulse of Diversity in the Media|last=|first=|date=March 2009|publisher=European Commission|year=|isbn=978-92-79-12419-8|location=Belgium|pages=}}</ref> the [[International Federation of Journalists]],<ref name=":0" /> [[Article 19]],<ref name=":1">{{cite book|last1=Rupar|first1=Verica|title=Getting the Facts Right: Reporting Ethnicity & Religion|date=2012|publisher=MDI & International Federation of Journalists|location=Belgium}}</ref> and the [[European Federation of Journalists]].<ref name=":1" /> MDI is also a member of the [[Ethical Journalism Network]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Reporting on Migration and Refugees Training Workshop for EU Journalists|url=http://ethicaljournalismnetwork.org/reporting-migration-refugees-training-workshop-eu-journalists|website=Ethical Journalism Network}}</ref>
== Background == MDI was founded in 1997<ref name=":2" /> by journalist Milica Pesic, who was working at the time for NYU Center for War, Peace and the News Media.<ref>{{cite web|title=World Press Freedom Day 2017|url=http://en.unesco.org/world-press-freedom-day-2017/milica-pesic|website=UNESCO}}</ref> MDI works on an international scale, but has a European focus.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=buXzDQAAQBAJ&lpg=PA1&pg=PA3#v=onepage&q&f=false|title=Media and Cultural Policy in the European Union|last=Kretzschmar|first=Sonja|publisher=Rodopi|year=2007|isbn=9789401204156|editor-last=Sarikakis|editor-first=Katharine|location=Amsterdam|pages=215|chapter=Diverse Journalists in a Diverse Europe?}}</ref>
MDI works to engage, educate and train the actors in society who have influence over media coverage of diversity.<ref name=":3" /> This includes media decision makers (owners, editors, managers), journalists, academics, students, [[Social Movement Organization|Civil Society Organisations]] and governmental organisations.<ref name=":2" /><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-106391301.html|title=European Media Institute Publishes Manuals on Media and Diversity|last=|first=|date=7 August 2003|work=Info-Prod Research|access-date=5 October 2017|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|subscription=yes|via=HighBeam Research}}</ref> They also organize conferences on these topics.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-87676017.html|title=Diversity Reporting Program Planned for South Caucasus|last=|first=|date=23 June 2002|work=Info-Prod Research|access-date=5 October 2017|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|subscription=yes|via=HighBeam Research}}</ref>
== Projects == MDI's first large scale media diversity project, The Reporting Diversity Network (RDN), was launched at a conference in November 1998 with keynote speakers [[Michael Ignatieff]] and Jean-Paul Marthoz.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Tuller|first1=David|title=Reporting Diversity Manuel|date=2002|publisher=Media Diversity Institute & European Union|location=London|page=14|url=http://www.cestim.it/argomenti/08media/2002-Reporting-Diversity-Manual-Balkan-EN.pdf}}</ref> RDN's work focused on Central and Eastern Europe as well as the newly independent former Soviet states.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Pesic|first1=Milica|title=The Media's Markers of Race and Ethnicity in the Balkans|journal=Rhodes Journalism Review|date=August 2001|volume=2001|issue=20|pages=24–25|url=http://journals.co.za/content/rujr/2001/20/EJC144721;jsessionid=UgRbGlGP3pWXxTOUvp_u967d.sabinetlive}}</ref> They have also been involved in addressing the deaths of [[Romani people|Romani]] journalists and editors.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Gross|first=Peter|date=29 November 2006|title=A Prolegomena to the Study of the Romani Media in Eastern Europe|url=https://www.researchgate.net/profile/Peter_Gross6/publication/249720670_A_Prolegomena_to_the_Study_of_the_Romani_Media_in_Eastern_Europe/links/56e8191808aea51e7f3b153e/A-Prolegomena-to-the-Study-of-the-Romani-Media-in-Eastern-Europe.pdf|journal=European Journal of Communication|volume=21|issue=4|pages=485|doi=10.1177/0267323106070012|via=}}</ref>
Other projects that MDI have been involved in include Dune Voices,<ref>{{cite web|title=About Dune Voices|url=http://www.dune-voices.info/public/index.php/en/about-us/about-dune-voices|website=Dune Voices}}</ref> Get the Trolls Out,<ref>{{cite web|title=How to Counter Hate Speech on Twitter|url=http://www.stoppinghate.getthetrollsout.org/|website=Stopping Hate}}</ref> and Media Against Hate.<ref>{{cite web|title=About Media Against Hate|url=http://europeanjournalists.org/mediaagainsthate/|website=Media Against Hate}}</ref>
== In other media == The collaboration between MDI and [[Twitter]] in developing a guide on countering hate speech was referred to in an article in the ''[[Financial Times]]'', October 17, 2016.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Madhumita Murgia|first1=Hannah Kuchler|title=Social Media: Challenging the Jihadi Narrative|url=https://www.ft.com/content/3b03edde-8992-11e6-8aa5-f79f5696c731|agency=Financial Times|date=October 17, 2016}}</ref>
A video broadcast produced by MDI's Dune Voices project was published on the BBC website on December 30, 2016.<ref>{{cite web|title=In Mali: Artwork from Motorcycle Parts|url=http://www.bbc.com/arabic/media-38470942?SThisFB|website=BBC Arabic|publisher=Dune Sounds}}</ref>
MDI contributed to the Journal for Applied Journalism and Media Studies in 2017. MDI’s founder Milica Pesic presented concrete and detailed examples of how MDI has worked to promote inclusive journalism and diversity in the media in many different countries and regions. <ref>{{cite web|title="I’ve never interviewed ordinary people. We use them only in vox pops"|url=http://www.ingentaconnect.com/contentone/intellect/ajms/2017/00000006/00000003/art00011|website=Intellect|publisher=Journal of Applied Journalism & Media Studies, Volume 6, Number 3}}</ref>
== References == {{reflist}}
== External links == * [http://www.media-diversity.org/en/ Media Diversity Institute Official Website]
[[Category:1997 establishments in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Communications and media organisations based in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Mass media]]
